body: Cashflow in/out transactions to process the exchange on the contract date. For FX Spots and FX Forwards, you get two cashflows at the end of the contract. FA Swaps produce two cashflows in the beginning and two cashflows at the end of the contract.

title: View contract information
body: To view the contract you created:

title: View contract information
body: Find the Add Contract transaction in the Overview or in the Transactions view. The Add Contract transaction:

title: View contract information
body: Doesn't have any transaction effects. The amount is specified as 1, and other numeric values available as columns are shown as 0.

title: View contract information
body: Is linked to the contract security that is created automatically. You can see the contract security name that indicates the contract type, date, cashflows, and FX rate. For example, FX FWD #36 2019-05-02: USD +10000.00 / EUR -8901.55 (1.123).

title: View contract information
body: Double-click the transaction row to open the Contract window and view the contract details.

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: If a contract involves forward cashflows, you can see them as portfolio positions in the Overview. The position row shows:

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: The contract value, at the rate agreed in the contract:

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: In the cashflow currency ( Amount filed)

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: In the portfolio currency (Purchase value field)

title: View forward cashflows and track discounted present value
body: The discounted present value in the Market value field. Forward cashflow positions are revaluated daily using yield curves. The system calculates the discounted present value of each forward cashflow with the yield curves defined in the system, and uses these discount factors to calculate each day’s market value of your forward cashflow positions.

title: Analyze currency exposure
body: You can see the currency exposure of the portfolio investments in Analytics+. To do this, group the analysis by currency.

title: Close a contract
body: On the contract date, the system transfers the cash between accounts and closes forward cashflow positions.

title: Modify a contract
body: To modify any contract information, edit the contract in the Contract window securities and transactions are updated accordingly..

title: Modify a contract
body: Click the Add contract transaction in the Overview.

title: Modify a contract
body: Edit the contract details in the Contract window that opens and save the changes.

title: Modify a contract
body: Once you save the changes, the system updates:

title: Modify a contract
body: Contract security, including the security name. All categorizations or allocations you added remain untouched.

title: Modify a contract
body: Forward cashflow securities. If the previously used forward cashflow securities are in use in another portfolio, they are left untouched, or if not used, deleted from the system.

title: Modify a contract
body: Forward cashflow transactions: Counter, Counter portfolio, Market place, Settlement place, Description on statement and Internal info fields are filled in based on the contract details.

title: Modify a contract
body: Forward cashflow positions (portfolio report data is recalculated).

title: Modify a contract
body: Contract cashflows.

title: Deleting a contract
body: To delete your contract:

title: Deleting a contract
body: Click the Add contract transaction in the Overview.

title: Deleting a contract
body: Click in the Contract window that opens.

title: Deleting a contract
body: When you delete the contract, the system deletes all linked securities, transactions and positions and recalculates portfolio report data.

title: Deleting a contract
body: Do not try to delete contract securities and transactions - delete the contract itself to ensure everything gets deleted correctly.

title: Valuation of forward cashflows
body: For valuating forward cashflows, the system calculates the discounted present value of each forward cashflow using yield curves defined in the system. Valuating forward cashflows is a relevant part of managing FX contracts' forward cashflows, but also allows you to manage other forward cashflows, such as Certificates of deposits.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: To valuate forward cashflows, make sure you have appropriate forward cashflow securities in the system. The forward cashflow securities represent a forward cashflow on a given currency on a given date, and you can reuse the forward cashflow securities on the same currency and date.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: For FX Contracts, forward cashflow securities are created automatically when saving a contract. If you want to manage other forward cashflows, you can create forward cashflow securities with the following information:

title: Basic info
body: Status

title: Basic info
body: Status should be set to Active. Valuation is automatically done only on active securities.

title: Basic info
body: Type

title: Basic info
body: Type should use the base type DISCOUNT. Valuation is done only on securities with the base type discount.

title: Basic info
body: Currency

title: Basic info
body: Currency should be set based on the currency of the forward cashflow. Currency is used to find the appropriate discount yield curve from the curve group linking the currency to a curve.

title: Extra info
body: Maturity date

title: Extra info
body: Maturity date should be set as the the maturity date of the forward cashflow. Maturity date is used when calculating the discount factors on the forward cashflow - discount factors are calculated up until the maturity date, and at the maturity date, the discount factor corresponds with the maturity price.

title: Extra info
body: Maturity price

title: Extra info
body: Maturity price should be set to 1. Maturity price is used when calculating the discount factors on the forward cashflows - on the maturity date, the discount factor corresponds with the maturity price.

title: Calculating discount factors based on yield curves
body: The system calculates discounted present value of forward cashflows based on:

title: Calculating discount factors based on yield curves
body: Yield curve that provides interest rates (yields) for different maturities.

title: Calculating discount factors based on yield curves
body: Discount factors that indicate how to valuate a forward cashflow on a given date. The discount factors are stored in the forward cashflow security's Market data info tab, Close 5 field. Discount factors are calculated from the beginning of the first position in the security (when the forward cashflow position is opened with the first transaction) until the maturity date of your forward cashflow security, defined in the Extra info tab. On the maturity date, the discount factor equals to the maturity price defined for your forward cashflow security.

title: Calculating discount factors based on yield curves
body: The discount factors can directly be used to valuate the forward cashflow: amount * discount factor = market value.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: After you have set up your forward cashflow securities correctly and have defined yield curves for all the currencies you want to valuate forward cashflows for, the system provides you with tools for automatic and manual valuation of your forward cashflow securities. Valuation is always done for all appropriate securities regardless of their status.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: To keep your forward cashflows up-to-date, the automatic nightly report update valuates all your forward cashflows with new discount factors based on latest yield curve prices. The system automatically valuates your forward cashflows in the following situations:

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: When saving / modifying a contract that induces forward cashflows. Discount factors are automatically calculated from the beginning of the forward cashflow (i.e. usually from the beginning of the contract) until yesterday (or maturity date, if that is in the past). If the forward cashflow security already exists, only missing discount factors are calculated for the past in case the new contract starts earlier than discount factors currently exist.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: During the nightly report data update. Discount factors are automatically calculated daily during the nightly report data update, ensuring you get a new discount factor on your forward cashflows with the latest yield curve prices.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: If you are connected to a market data connector to fetch latest end-of-day prices automatically at night, the discount factors are calculated after the new market data observations have been fetched from the connector. Discount factors are calculated for as many days as you get prices for, i.e. as configures in Number of days market prices are fetched for in the nightly run in Market data connector Preferences. Existing discount factors are updated in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: If you are not connected to a market data connector, the discount factors are calculated as Valuate missing valuations for all securities.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: When fetching market data from a market data connector through the Update menu. Discount factors are automatically calculated every time you fetch new market data observations through the menu - this will fetch new prices for you interest rates involved in your yield curves, thus discount factors are recalculated with the new prices. Discount factors are calculated for the same time period you selected to fetch prices for (e.g. 7 days), and Get missing market prices will Valuate missing valuations for all securities. Existing discount factors are updated in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: In addition, you can manually revaluate your forward cashflow securities through the Security window or Update menu if the appropriate permission to revaluate securities has been enabled for your user role. You can manually valuate your forward cashflows in the following situations:

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate close 5 button in the Security window's Market data info tab is available for securities with base type DISCOUNT and other relevant information. Clicking the button will calculate discount factors

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Since the latest existing observation until yesterday or until maturity date, if that is in the past (i.e. since the latest discount factor you can see in the close 5 field until the day you can expect to have close prices for your yield curve interest rates).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: If your forward cashflow security doesn't yet have any discount factors, since the beginning of the first position in the security (i.e. when the forward cashflow position is opened with the first transaction) until yesterday or until maturity date, if that is in the past. If you create a forward cashflow security and don't yet have a position on it in a portfolio, discount factors are not calculated.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: If you want to revaluate the entire history of your forward cashflow, first Delete Close 5 prices and then Revaluate close 5.

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities menu items in the Update menu allow you to recalculate the discount factors for a specific time period on all your securities with the base type DISCOUNT and other relevant information. Discount factors on a security are never calculated before the beginning of the position or after the maturity date, and all calculations are done until yesterday. Revaluating securities will always trigger a report recalculation to update the effect of the new values to your portfolios - report recalculation will affect all portfolios that contain the securities that receive a new valuation. Options available in the menu are:

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities for past 7 days - recalculates the discount factors for past 7 days, updating the existing discount factors in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities for past 30 days - recalculates the discount factors for past 30 days, updating the existing discount factors in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities for past 365 days - recalculates the discount factors for past 365 days, updating the existing discount factors in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Revaluate all securities from [date] - recalculates the discount factors from the shown date (configured Earliest market price date in Market data connector Preferences) onward, updating the existing discount factors in Close 5 field (other entries not touched).

title: Automatic and manual valuation
body: Valuate missing valuations for all securities - recalculates the discount factors since the latest existing observation for each security. This option goes through all relevant securities one-by-one, determines per each security the latest available discount factor, and recalculates discount factors for that security from that date onward. If your forward cashflow security doesn't yet have any discount factors, discount factors are calculated since the beginning of the first position in the security. Depending on the history, your discount might be calculated for different time periods for different securities, depending what their latest available observation is - this option allows you to calculate "valuations that are newer than the newest observation already stored".

title: Securities, transactions and positions related to FX contract
body: The diagram shows the structure of securities, transactions and positions created by the system to process the contract:

title: Securities, transactions and positions related to FX contract
body: Forward cashflow positions and contract transactions are important when you work with the contract.

title: Securities, transactions and positions related to FX contract
body: Securities and transactions marked with the dotted line are not seen in the Overview and aren't needed for regular contract handling. They are used by the system to store and manage the data. Making changes in these securities and transactions is not recommended – instead, you should edit the contract you created.

title: Contract
body: The contract itself can be accessed by clicking Add contract transaction in the Overview or Transactions view.

title: Contract

title: Contract
body: Amount is set to 1, and other numeric values available as columns are shown as 0 - open the contract window to see the details and values related to your contract.

title: Contract security

title: Contract security
body: Code

title: Contract security

title: Contract security

title: Contract security
body: FX SPOT [date yyyy-MM-dd]: [first cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [first cashflow's Amount] / [second cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [second cashflow's Amount] ([FX rate])

title: Contract security
body: FX FWD #[security external ID] [date yyyy-MM-dd]: [first cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [first cashflow's Amount] / [second cashflow's Currency] [+ for Buy / - for Sell] [second cashflow's Amount] ([FX rate])

title: Contract security

title: Contract security
body: Status

title: Contract security
body: Status is set to Passive to ensure that the contract doesn't appear in your security listings. You can't create transactions for contract securities, so the contract securities don't need to appear as active.

title: Contract security
body: Type

title: Contract security

title: Contract security

title: Contract security

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Forward cashflow securities are created if the contract induces forward cashflows. A forward cashflow security is a combination of a cashflow, currency and a maturity date, for example "1000 USD bought on 2024-08-08".

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: You can find forward cashflow securities in the Securities view.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Code

title: Forward cashflow securities

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Name

It includes contract type, maturity date of the forward cashflow, currency code of the forward cashflow currency and value of the cashflow with the syntax TYPE #EXTERNAL_ID yyyy-MM-dd CURRENCY +/- cashflow (e.g. FX FWD #34 2019-11-29 EUR -9.1k). The date depends on your selection in contract preferences (transaction date or settlement date).

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: The cashflow amount is shortened to the number of thousands (K), millions (M), billions (B) or trillions (T). No rounding is applied.

title: Forward cashflow securities

title: Forward cashflow securities

title: Forward cashflow securities

body: Linked security

title: Forward cashflow securities

This allows the system to track which forward cashflows are generated based on which contract, and for example to show the contract in the transaction listing on the Overview when clicking a forward cashflow position. You cannot edit your forward cashflows' linked security afterwards.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Maturity date (Extra info tab)

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Maturity date of the forward cashflow ( set to transaction date or settlement date, depending on contract preferences). Maturity date is used when calculating the discount factors on the forward cashflows - discount factors are calculated only up until the maturity date, and at the maturity date, the discount factor corresponds to the maturity price.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Maturity price (Extra info tab)

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Maturity price is set to 1. Maturity price is used when calculating the discount factors on the forward cashflows - on the maturity date, the discount factor corresponds to the maturity price.

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Market data info tab

title: Forward cashflow securities
body: Market data info tab contains the daily discount factors in the Close 5 field, calculated for the forward cashflow security from the beginning of the contract (i.e. the contract date) up until the maturity date of the forward cashflow security. The system calculates the discount factors with yield curves, and the discount factors are used to valuate the forward cashflow positions in your portfolios.

title: Forward cashflow transactions
body: Forward cashflow transactions are created if the contract induces forward cashflows. You can find these transactions in the Overview or in the Transactions view. Forward cashflow transactions have no cash effect. They create future cashflow positions in the portfolio.

title: Forward cashflow transactions

title: Forward cashflow transactions

title: Forward cashflow transactions
body: Counter, Counter portfolio, Market place, Settlement place, Description, Internal info and Tags are filled in based on the information you filled in on the contract. This ensures the transactions generated based on your contracts are categorized consistently, allowing you for example to search and report them.

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: When you save a contract, the system recalculates the portfolio's reporting data to show the forward cashflow positions for both legs of the contract, opened with the forward cashflow transactions. The forward cashflow positions are open from the start of the contract until the cashflowscashflows take effect at the end of the contract.

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: You'll get one positive and one negative forward cashflow position. The Market value of the forward cashflow position tells you the discounted present value of the forward cashflow on the selected date. The system calculates the discounted present value of each forward cashflow with the yield curves defined in the system (see Preference - Yield curves).

title: Forward cashflow positions
body: Forward cashflows are valuated automatically during nightly report update based on latest yield curve prices. In addition, you can manually revaluate your forward cashflow securities in the Market data info tab in the -security window or Top menu.

title: Investment objectives
body: FA Platform lets you manage investment objectives and model your portfolios with the following tools:

title: Model portfolio, investment plan, strategy
body: You set investment objectives on different levels - defining asset allocations and their shares, or specifying particular securities to include in the portfolio. You can use the same investment objectives across portfolios or tailor them to a certain client.

title: Model portfolio, investment plan, strategy
body: Model portfolio is a sample basket of investments used to maintain and rebalance client portfolios. For details, see Model portfolio.

title: Model portfolio, investment plan, strategy
body: Investment plan is a client-specific portfolio model that includes securities and their shares. An investment plan can be composite, created as a combination of model portfolios (for example 20% of stock portfolio and 80% of bond portfolio). Investment plan is used for rebalancing. For details, see Investment plan.

title: Model portfolio, investment plan, strategy
body: Strategy is a model that sets the desired allocation for your portfolio – it includes asset types and their shares. A strategy can be created as a combination of model portfolios. For example, 60% share of a model portfolio that contains equities and 40% share of a model portfolio that contains bonds. Strategy is used for rebalancing and portfolio analysis: it lets you see if your portfolio allocation follows the plan and track the portfolio drift. For details, see Strategy.

title: Limit analysis
body: Limits analysis allows you to check if a portfolio follows the model portfolio, investment plan or strategy. Besides these models, limits can be based on Analytics+ values, such as market value, and on the profile values. For details, see Limit analysis.

title: Rebalacing
body: To rebalance a portfolio against a model portfolio, investment plan, or a strategy, see Rebalance.

title: Strategy
body: A strategy sets the desired allocation for your portfolio. It lets you track if your portfolio allocation follows the plan and run portfolio rebalancing.  A strategy can be:

title: Strategy
body: Shared or portfolio-specific. You can define a strategy per portfolio or reuse it in multiple portfolios.

title: Strategy
body: Based on asset types or on a model portfolio. Asset types allow you to allocate investments by geographical areas, industry, or types of holdings like stocks or bonds.  A model portfolio represents a basket of investments (to learn more about how to create a model portfolio, see Model portfolio window)

title: Strategy
body: Regular or interpolated. Regular strategy is based on the dates and shares that you entered. For example, you can set a strategy that is valid from 01.01.2022 and contains 20% of a certain asset type. Then, you can raise the asset type share, for example, to 22% starting from 01.03.2023, and so on. Interpolated strategy is based on the shares on the start and end date of the period. The system calculates the values between the dates to create a gradual change that occurs on business days. For example, if you want to reduce investments in a particular sector from 30% to 20% over 5 years, you can enter two dates and specify the start and end shares. The values in between the dates will be calculated automatically.

title: Strategy
body: A portfolio can contain multiple strategies, for example, for asset allocation, geographical allocation, and industrial allocation. However, only one strategy is allowed if you use interpolation.

title: Create a strategy
body: To set up a strategy for your portfolio:

title: Create a strategy
body: Make sure you have allocations and model portfolio information in place:

title: Create a strategy
body: If your strategy is based on the asset types, make sure you allocated your securities with asset classes and types (see Security window). The list of asset types is pre-configured in the system and you can create your own ones in Preferences (see Preference - Securities).

title: Create a strategy
body: If your strategy is based on a model portfolio, create an asset type based on your model portfolio in Preference → Securities: add an asset group and asset type and choose the model portfolio in the Linked model portfolio field.

title: Create a strategy
body: Define a strategy for your portfolio in the Portfolio window → Strategy tab. Add the date from which the strategy is valid and specify the minimum and maximum percentage for each asset type. The total percentage must sum up to 100%.

title: Create a strategy
body: You can set up an interpolated strategy that changes gradually between the dates – for example, if you want to reduce investments in a particular sector from 30% to 20% over 5 years, you can enter two dates and specify the start and end share percentage. The values in between the dates will be calculated automatically. For details about strategy settings in the Portfolio window, see Strategy).

title: Reuse a strategy in other portfolios
body: Once you created a strategy for one portfolio, you can reuse it by linking it to other portfolios:

title: Reuse a strategy in other portfolios
body: For the portfolio to which you want to link the strategy, open Portfolio window → Strategy tab.

title: Reuse a strategy in other portfolios
body: Choose the source portfolio in the Strategy from portfolio field, then choose the asset group. The content of the strategy is shown. Note that if the strategy is updated in the source portfolio, changes will be applied to this portfolio strategy as well.

title: Reuse a strategy in other portfolios
body: Save the changes.

title: Compare portfolio allocation to a strategy
body: Compare portfolio allocation to a strategy

title: Compare portfolio allocation to a strategy
body: Once you set up a strategy, you can track if your portfolio follows it:

title: Compare portfolio allocation to a strategy
body: Analyze if your portfolio allocation follows the strategy and check for strategy breaches that require action. To do this, set up limits based on strategy in Preference → Portfolios → Limit definitions, link the limit group to the portfolio in the Portfolio window, Limits tab. This feature is available only for regular non-interpolated strategy. For detailed instruction, see Limit definitions based on strategy, investment plan or model portfolio.

title: Compare portfolio allocation to a strategy
body: Compare the portfolio performance to the strategy. Open Strategy analyzer to view the portfolio data next to the strategy figures in a table. To learn more, see Strategy analyzer.

title: Compare portfolio allocation to a strategy
body: Make a long-term analysis of portfolio allocation against the strategy in Drift Tracker. This feature is available only for regular non-interpolated strategy. To learn more, see Analyze and monitor portfolios' drift.

title: Rebalance
body: Rebalancing helps you realign your portfolio positions with your model – a model portfolio, investment plan, or strategy. The system compares portfolios with the model and generates trade orders for positions that deviated outside the minimum and maximum thresholds specified in the model.

title: Rebalancing settings and parameters
body: The details of the rebalancing process are set in the system preferences and defined further when you run rebalancing:

title: Rebalancing settings and parameters
body: System-wide settings in preferences include options related to cash usage, trade order generation, and market prices to use. See Preference - Portfolios in FA Back reference.

title: Rebalancing settings and parameters
body: Before you rebalance, read about the general rebalancing logic below. Decide which rebalancing approach to choose: conservative rebalance, full rebalance, full rebalance including outstanding orders, exchange, invest cash, cover for cash, and model change (see Rebalance methods). Once you chose the approach, select the rebalancing parameters and run rebalancing: define the affected portfolios, select the portfolio positions and accounts to include in the run, and specify the rebalancing and trade order generation parameters. See the instructions in Rebalance portfolios against a model portfolio, Rebalance portfolios against an investment plan , Rebalance portfolios against a strategy and the field descriptions in Rebalance window.

title: Rebalance logic
body: When a portfolio is rebalanced, the system creates the trade orders based on the following logic.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Estimates the excess cash by checking if the portfolio's account balance is above the share of cash in the model. The estimation includes the accounts you chose and the cash from sells, if chosen.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Compares portfolio positions to the model:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Calculates the difference for each position in portfolio currency.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Calculates the number of units you would need based on the difference in portfolio currency and the market price on the selected date. Number of shares is calculated with as many decimals as defined in security type preferences, or overridden with the security block size.

title: Rebalance logic
body: Creates trade orders:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Buy trade orders are created first. Then the system creates sell trade orders. Buy trade orders are created, from largest to smallest, as long as there is excess cash in the portfolio. The last trade order might be only partially fulfilled. Sell trade orders are created with the same logic: from largest to smallest, until the target cash balance is reached.

title: Rebalance logic
body: If the difference per position measured in portfolio currency doesn't match a whole number of units (see the previous step), the system adjusts the trade orders following the logic defined in the rebalancing settings in Preferences . Trade orders are recalculated based on:

title: Rebalance logic
body: Amount (using the calculated number of units and difference, and recalculating the unit price)

title: Rebalance logic
body: Trade amount (using the calculated number of units and unit price, and recalculating the trade amount)

title: Rebalance logic
body: For details, see "Create trade orders based on trade amount" and "Create trade orders based on trade amount" in Rebalancing.

title: Rebalancing against strategy
body: A strategy sets the target per allocation share (not per position). When rebalancing against strategy, FA system calculates the asset type share in the portfolio. If this asset type is below or above the target, the system suggests buys or sells for the securities in the asset type. To learn more, see Rebalance portfolios against a strategy.

title: Rebalancing portfolio cash
body: To keep portfolio's cash on a certain level, add the currency security as a position in the investment plan or model portfolio and specify the target share. For example, if you have EUR accounts in your portfolio and want to have 1% cash in euros, add the currency security EUR with a target share of 1%.

title: Rebalancing portfolio cash
body: You can choose to rebalance only accounts, leaving out the portfolio positions when you run rebalancing (see the options described in Rebalance window). For the system settings related to accounts and cash buffers in rebalancing, see Preference - Portfolios in FA Back reference.

title: Available cash for buys
body: You can define if you want to create buy trade orders only with available cash or use the cash received from sells as well (see Rebalance methods). If you use the cash from sells, you can define the share of sells to be used for buys, to make sure you have some cash buffer if the prices fluctuate. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Available cash for buys
body: Cash from existing outstanding trade orders can also be used for buys (see Rebalance methods).

title: Market prices
body: By default, rebalancing uses the latest market prices in relation to the selected rebalancing date. By default, the market prices and relevant FX rates stored in FA Back are used. You can choose to use the 15-minute delayed market prices from your market data provider. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Trade amount and number of units in suggested trade orders
body: The system adjusts the trade amount or the number of units in the trade order if they don't match (for example, you need to buy for 300€, the unit price is 80€, and the security is traded in whole units). For details, see "Create trade orders based on trade amount" and "Create trade orders based on trade amount" in Rebalancing.

title: Trade amount and number of units in suggested trade orders
body: The number of units in the trade order is calculated with the number of decimals defined in security type preferences, or taken from the security's block size (if it is specified).

title: Trade amount and number of units in suggested trade orders
body: To prevent the creation of small trade orders when the investment portfolio only slightly deviates from the target, you can set the minimum trade order amount. See the options described in Rebalance window). This setting is not applied if you remove a position from the model to sell it away completely.

title: Selling an entire position
body: Rebalancing recognizes when you sell out the entire position by removing it from the model. In this case:

title: Selling an entire position
body: The minimum trade amount of the orders has no effect - the sell orders are generated without size restrictions.

title: Selling an entire position
body: The amount of the order isn't adjusted, but corresponds with the current position amount in the portfolio.

title: Selling an entire position
body: If rebalancing is restricted to accounts, entire positions are not sold unless there is "room to sell" based on the target cash balance.

title: Selling an entire position
body: Rebalancing marks such trade orders by creating them with a separate transaction type, as configured in "Select the transaction type used for trade orders when selling an entire position" in Rebalancing preferences (see Rebalancing). Rebalancing creates these trade orders as unit-based.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: Rebalancing supports including future contracts in the model. The Futures and Forwards security types have the "Future contract" setting defined in Preference - Securities - Security types.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: For forwards, the setting is "Yes - charge cost later". Buying a future based on the model portfolio share doesn't deduct the available cash.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: For futures, the setting is "Yes - charge cost immediately". Buying a future based on the model portfolio share deducts the available cash only for the amount of cost, if rebalancing is set to calculate fees.

title: Future contracts in rebalancing
body: For both options, selling a future doesn't add to the available cash if one of the options for using cash from sells is used.

title: Collateral in rebalancing
body: To manage collateral in rebalancing, transfer collateral positions from the main portfolio into a locked sub-portfolio. When rebalancing the main portfolio, the collateral positions from the sub-portfolio are taken into account when determining how much to buy or sell in total, but the collateralized positions in the locked sub-portfolio are not touched.

title: Related links
body: Model portfolio management in FA Back reference

title: Related links
body: Model Portfolio Management and Rebalancing in FA Product description

title: Rebalance portfolios against a strategy
body: Strategy rebalancing makes sure your portfolio follows allocation shares defined in the strategy. If an asset type is below or above the target, the system suggests buys or sells to increase the portfolio positions proportionally. If an asset type is missing from the portfolio (for example, the strategy requires 10% Finnish stocks but the portfolio doesn't have any), the system suggests equally-sized trade orders for each security in the missing asset type from your buy list.

title: Rebalance portfolios against a strategy
body: Strategy rebalancing doesn't adjust holdings within the asset type. For example, if Finnish holdings in the portfolio are represented by one security, rebalancing considers this sufficient. It doesn't suggest sells to buy other Finnish stocks from the buy list.

title: Rebalance portfolios against a strategy
body: Strategy rebalancing works only for equity portfolios. It should not be used with funds and ETFs that are allocated to several asset types (for example, a fund security can be allocated as 70% US and 30% Canada).

title: Rebalance portfolios against a strategy
body: To use a strategy for rebalancing portfolios, follow the steps:

title: Step 1 – Create a buy list
body: To start with strategy rebalancing, you need to create a buy list. Allocate securities that will be involved in this process, include them in a security group and link this group to the investment portfolios.

title: Step 1 – Create a buy list
body: Create a security group with the securities that will be available for buys. Go to Groups → Security groups and create a static or dynamic group. To learn more about security groups, see Groups view.

title: Step 1 – Create a buy list
body: Link this security group to the portfolios you rebalance in the Portfolio window, Security groups tab. For more information about linking, see Security groups.

title: Step 1 – Create a buy list
body: Make sure that securities in the security group are allocated with the asset types (the same ones as your strategy uses). To allocate securities, go to Security window , Allocation tab.

title: Step 1 – Create a buy list
body: Now you set up securities that are included in rebalancing against a strategy.

title: Step 2 – Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: To rebalance investment portfolios against the strategy and create trade orders:

title: Step 2 – Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Depending on your business case, choose one of the options to rebalance investment portfolios:

title: Step 2 – Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance a single portfolio. Select the investment portfolio on the Overview. Right-click it on the right and choose Rebalancing. Select "Strategy" in the Rebalance against field.

title: Step 2 – Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance selected portfolios against the strategies linked to them. Search the investment portfolios on the Portfolios view, click Rebalance at the bottom. Select "Strategy" in the Rebalance against field.

title: Step 2 – Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Define rebalancing parameters. Choose the asset group the strategy is based on, set the rebalancing logic, and trade order generation options. For more information about the fields, see Rebalance window. Check the error notifications by clicking above table. If any data (strategy or securities in the security groups linked to the portfolios), the system informs you about this.

title: Step 2 – Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: If needed, adjust the target security shares in the table. Once you defined all parameters, click Rebalance.

title: Step 2 – Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: View the trade orders suggested by the system.

title: Step 2 – Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Use the filters at the top to adjust the list of trade orders. Once you are satisfied with the list, click Save. Note that only visible trade orders are saved. To save all suggested trade orders, clear all filters before saving.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: To execute the trade orders:

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Search for the created trade orders in the Trade orders view and set their status to "Executable". Send the executable trade orders forward to buy and sell securities to the investment portfolios.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Once the trades are implemented in the market, execute trade orders in FA with the realized values to create transactions to the investment portfolios.

title: Add trade orders
body: You can create trade orders from scratch or based on a portfolio position, for example, to sell or buy a security already in your portfolio. You can also create trade orders based on a position in multiple portfolios for partial redemptions or security switches.

title: Add trade orders
body: Adding a trade order in a portfolio doesn't affect portfolio positions. Portfolio positions and cash amounts are recalculated when a transaction is accepted.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: To create a trade order from scratch, do the following:

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: In the Overview, select the portfolio in which you want to add a trade order. If you select the portfolio first, the trade order is directly linked to the correct portfolio.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Click New trade order in the New menu (top left) and select a security type.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Fill in the fields in the Trade order window. For descriptions of the fields, see Trade order window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a trade order from scratch
body: Save the trade order.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: To create a new trade order based on the position in the selected portfolio, do the following:

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: In the Overview, right-click the position row and select New.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Select Trade order with position's security and amount.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Fill in the fields. For descriptions of the fields, see Trade order window in FA Back reference.

title: Add a position-based trade order in a selected portfolio
body: Save the trade order.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: You can create trade orders based on a position in multiple portfolios, for example, to do partial redemptions or switches from one security to another using the reinvest option.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: To create trade orders based on the position in multiple portfolios, do the following:

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: In the Positions view, search for a position to use as a starting point.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Create transactions and fill in the fields in the Generate transactions from positions window:

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Create: The type of object to create. Select "Trade orders".

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction type: The transaction type to use. The list of available types depends on the selected security.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Execution method: The trade order execution method.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Amount: The amount as percentage of the original position size.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Unit price: The unit price to use in the trade orders. Enter a question mark to get the latest price available in the system.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Transaction date

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Settlement date

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Tags: The tags for the trade orders.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: If the selected transaction type has a positive cash effect, reinvest by clicking Add security and filling in the fields, including the security to reinvest in. You can reinvest into multiple securities.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Preview trade orders to check the trade orders to be created. You can uncheck trade orders you don't want the system to create.

title: Add position-based trade orders in multiple portfolios
body: Click Confirm.

title: Rebalance methods
body: FA platform lets you set multiple rebalancing parameters to control how the rebalancing logic calculates what to buy and sell. You can combine the parameters in various ways. Below are the most common rebalance methods, with the parameters to use for each of them.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: With conservative rebalancing, you can purchase securities using only the cash in the portfolio account. You can realign the portfolio with the model in two rounds. In the first round, the system sells the excess positions above the target and buys with the available cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys additional positions with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect conservative rebalancing in the following way:

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Conservative rebalance
body: To apply the conservative rebalance method, choose "Conservative (buy only with extra cash in portfolio)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Full rebalance
body: With full rebalancing, you can buy securities using both available cash and the cash expected from suggested sales. This method calculates buys based on the estimated cash you will have after executing suggested sales with the latest market prices. With full rebalance, you can realign your entire portfolio against the model in one go.

title: Full rebalance
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Full rebalance
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect full rebalancing in the following way:

title: Full rebalance
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys.

title: Full rebalance
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Full rebalance
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Full rebalance
body: To apply this method, choose "Full (buy both with extra cash in portfolio and cash from sells)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: With full rebalance including outstanding orders, you can purchase securities using available cash, expected cash from recommended sells, and cash from outstanding trade orders with a positive cash effect (all statuses except "Open"), such as deposits and sells. Full rebalancing estimates available cash that will be received after executing all sells with the latest market prices. This method requires careful trade order management to ensure sufficient cash is available to complete your buys.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected to be available after executing these orders.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: With full rebalance including outstanding trade orders, you can realign your entire portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders.

title: Full rebalance including outstanding orders
body: To apply this method, choose "Full including orders (also buy with cash from orders)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Exchange
body: With exchange, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. The cash received from sells is estimated based on the latest market prices, putting pressure on your trade order management to ensure you settle your sell so that you have enough cash available to execute your buy.

title: Exchange
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") are considered in the exchange.

title: Exchange
body: Buy trade orders with negative cash effect reduce the available cash to reserve cash for buys. (However, exchange will not use the your cash balance for the suggested trade orders).

title: Exchange
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type for the same security are taken into account when the system suggests new trade orders. If you should buy something but you already have a buy trade order for that security, or if you should sell but already have a sell trade order for the security, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Exchange
body: Example: You would need to buy Security A for 100 €, but you already have a trade order to buy Security A for 40 €. Rebalancing would create a buy trade order worth 100 € - 40 € = 60 €.

title: Exchange
body: You can swap one position for another without rebalancing your entire portfolio. This process sells positions above the target and uses the proceeds to buy positions below the target. The weights of the positions ensure the new position matches the investment weight of the old one.

title: Exchange
body: To apply this method:

title: Exchange
body: Choose "Exchange (buy only with cash from sells)" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window. Do not restrict rebalancing to accounts.

title: Exchange
body: Select the positions you want to exchange.

title: Invest cash
body: With the invest cash method, you can only use the excess cash in your account to buy securities, without making any other changes. It calculates purchases based on the available cash but does not involve selling any positions.

title: Invest cash
body: To apply this method:

title: Invest cash
body: Choose Restrict rebalancing to accounts in the Rebalance window. This ensures that rebalancing will only buy with the excess cash you have, but will not sell anything.

title: Invest cash
body: Choose "Conservative (buy both with extra cash in portfolio" in the Rebalance method field in the Rebalance window.

title: Cover for cash
body: With the cover-for-cash method, you can only use sells to address a negative account balance without making any other changes to your portfolio. It calculates the necessary sells to reach your target cash level without generating additional sells or making any purchases. The rebalancing process only sells enough to cover the negative balance, preventing excess cash in the account, which this method aims to avoid.

title: Cover for cash
body: This method lets you sell a portion of your holdings to cover for a negative account balance, for example after withdrawing fees from the portfolio, without realigning the entire portfolio.

title: Cover for cash
body: To apply this method, choose Restrict rebalancing to accounts in the Rebalance window. This ensures that rebalancing will only sell to cover for the negative cash you have, but will not buy anything.

title: Model change
body: With the model change, you can update your portfolio model by selling the securities from the old model and investing everything into the securities in the new model.

title: Model change
body: You have an option to execute a model change either as Conservative rebalancing or Full rebalancing, depending on whether you prefer to do it gradually or all at once. Regardless of the method chosen, rebalancing will sell off your old positions entirely and reinvest the proceeds into the new positions.

title: Rebalance portfolios against a model portfolio
body: You can use model portfolios to keep the customers' investment portfolios in balance.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: To link the customer's investment portfolio to a model portfolio, do the following:

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Select the customer's portfolio and open the Portfolio window.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Select the model portfolio in the Basic info tab, Model portfolio field.

title: Step 1 - Link the investment portfolios to the model portfolios
body: Click Save.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: To rebalance the investment portfolios against model portfolios and create trade orders:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Depending on your business case, choose one of the options to rebalance investment portfolios:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance a single portfolio. Select the investment portfolio on the Overview. Right-click it on the right and choose Rebalancing.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance all investment portfolios linked to a model portfolio. Use one of the options to open the Rebalance window:

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Click Rebalancing on the Rebalance view and select the model portfolio you want to use.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Click the Rebalancing button in the Model portfolio window for the model portfolio you want to use.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Choose the investment portfolios you want to rebalance in the table.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Rebalance selected portfolios against the model portfolios linked to them. Search the investment portfolios on the Portfolios view, click Rebalance at the bottom and select one of the options that include "Model portfolio" in the Rebalance against field.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Define rebalancing parameters for affected portfolios, the rebalancing logic, and trade order generation options. If needed, adjust the security shares in the model portfolios in the table. For more information about the fields, see Rebalance window. Once you defined all parameters, click Rebalance.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: View the trade orders suggested by the system. Use the filters at the top to adjust the list of trade orders. Once you are satisfied with the list, click Save.

title: Step 2 - Rebalance investment portfolios to create trade orders
body: Note that only visible trade orders are saved. To save all suggested trade orders, clear all filters before saving.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: To execute the trade orders:

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Search for the created trade orders in the Trade orders view and set their status to "Executable". Send the executable trade orders forward to buy and sell securities to the investment portfolios.

title: Step 3 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Once the trades are implemented in the market, execute trade orders in FA with the realized values to create transactions to the investment portfolios.

title: Related links
body: Model portfolio management in FA Back reference

title: Related links
body: File formats for importing model portfolios in FA Back reference

title: Rebalance portfolios against an investment plan
body: You can use an investment plan to keep your investment portfolios in balance. Follow the steps below to rebalance your investment portfolios against their investment plans.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: To rebalance investment portfolios against the investment plan and create trade orders:

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Depending on your business case, choose one of the options to rebalance investment portfolios:

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Rebalance a single portfolio. Select the investment portfolio on the Overview. Right-click it on the right and choose Rebalancing.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Rebalance selected portfolios against the investment plans linked to them. Search the investment portfolios on the Portfolios view, click Rebalance at the bottom, and select one of the options that include "Investment plan" in the Rebalance against field.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Define rebalancing parameters for affected portfolios, the rebalancing logic, and trade order generation options. If needed, adjust the security shares in the investment plans in the table. For more information about the fields, see Rebalance window. Once you defined all parameters, click Rebalance.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: View the trade orders suggested by the system. Use the filters at the top to adjust the list of trade orders. Once you are satisfied with the list, click Save.

title: Step 1 - Rebalance investment portfolios to get buy and sell trade orders
body: Note that only visible trade orders are saved. To save all suggested trade orders, clear all filters before saving.

title: Step 2 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: To execute the trade orders:

title: Step 2 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Search for the created trade orders in the Trade orders view and set their status to "Executable". Send the executable trade orders forward to buy and sell securities to the investment portfolios.

title: Step 2 - Execute the trade orders to create transactions
body: Once the trades are implemented in the market, execute trade orders in FA with the realized values to create transactions to the investment portfolios.

title: Authority reporting
body: Authority reporting

title: Related links
body: Reporting in FA Back reference

title: Publish reports to documents
body: FA Back allows you to publish reports directly into the documents of contacts, portfolios, or trade orders. You can generate reports and then instantly publish them to your clients, for example, within your external environment. The following sections describe the process of publishing reports and how to delete them.

title: Step 1 - Select the report target
body: When publishing reports to documents, the way you should start the process depends on what you want to generate and publish reports for. In FA Back, you can:

title: Step 1 - Select the report target
body: Publish reports for a single contact. In the Overview, select the contact and click the icon. The New report window opens with your contact pre-selected.

title: Step 1 - Select the report target
body: Publish reports for a single portfolio. In the Overview, select the contact and portfolio, and click the icon. The New report window opens with your portfolio pre-selected.

title: Step 1 - Select the report target
body: Publish reports for groups of contacts or portfolios. Go to New → New report and select the reports to generate. Select a group in the Customer, group, portfolio field.

title: Step 1 - Select the report target
body: Publish reports for trade orders. In the Trade orders view, search for the trade orders you want to generate reports for or open a tab at the top of the view. Use the icon to open the New report window.

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: When you have selected the report target, you can define and generate the reports:

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: In the New report window, select the reports or report packages to generate and define the report parameters (see Report window in FA Back reference).

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Define the Output type for publishing the reports:

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Report per customer to documents

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Select this option if you want to publish reports for one or more contacts.

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Report per portfolio to documents

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Select this option if you want to publish reports for one or more portfolios.

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Report per trade order to documents

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Select this option if you want to publish reports for trade orders.

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Fill in the additional fields for publishing the reports:

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Folder name

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: When publishing reports to documents, the reports are also generated to a defined folder and can later be found in the Generated reports tab. The reports saved within the Generated reports tab are physically different files from the documents published in the documents of each customer, portfolio, or trade order (see Manage documents), and are stored there more as an "audit trail" on what's been generated in the background. Regardless of the folder name you define, reports are stored directly under the contact, portfolio, or trade order. The folder name only affects how the audit trail of generated reports is structured.

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Document name

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: You can set a common name for the report file, allowing you to easily name the published reports files consistently, for example as "Monthly report.pdf" or "Q1 Report.pdf". The published report appears with this file name in the documents of each customer, portfolio, or trade order. If you don't define a document name, your reports are saved with the name the report generation assigns them (the name the report file would get when printing it out directly).

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Document tags

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: You can add tags to categorize your report files within your documents - the tags you define here will be added to each of the report files. Tagging allows you to find your documents easily, and for example to show them in different sections within FA Front.

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: Click Generate reports.

title: Step 2 - Define and generate the reports
body: The system saves the generated reports directly to the documents of the contacts, portfolios, or trade orders (for example, as PDFs) instead of downloading the reports to your computer. You can view the reports in the Contact, Portfolio or Trade order window, Documents tab.

title: Delete published reports
body: Publishing reports per contact, portfolio, or trade order generates report files directly to the documents of individual contacts, portfolios, and trade orders. To delete the reports, you need to remove them from each contact, portfolio, or trade order (rather than deleting them directly in the New report window, Generated reports tab).

title: Delete published reports
body: You can delete reports one-by-one in the Contact, Portfolio or Trade order window. You can also mass-delete reports in the Administration view, Documents tab:

title: Delete published reports
body: Search for all the reports that were published so that they are visible in the view (enter a search criterion or select a tag to search with). Use the document name or tags you defined during publishing.

title: Delete published reports
body: Click Delete document. This deletes all reports currently visible.

title: Generate reports for transactions and trade orders
body: You can generate reports for selected transactions or trade orders. For example, if you need to report transactions that result from trade order execution, or all today's transactions or trade orders. Depending on how often you need to produce the report, you can use one of the options:

title: Generate reports for transactions and trade orders
body: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search. This option is convenient if you need to produce the report only once.

title: Generate reports for transactions and trade orders
body: Generate reports based on the saved search. This option is convenient if you need to generate reports more than once – for example, if you need to report all today's buy transactions every day. You can also schedule report generation.

title: Generate reports for transactions and trade orders
body: You can automatically create reports for the recent transactions or trade orders that have not been reported: Mark transactions and trade orders as reported with tags.

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: To generate reports for transactions or trade orders based on a search:

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Define the report scope:

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Search for transactions in the Overview (lower section) or in the Transactions view.

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Search for trade orders in the Trade orders view.

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Click the printer icon in the top-right corner of the view and choose the report options in the Report window that opens (see Report window in FA Back reference for details).

title: Generate reports based on an ad-hoc search
body: Click Generate report.

title: Generate reports based on the saved search
body: To generate reports for transactions or trade orders based on the saved search:

title: Generate reports based on the saved search
body: Open Transactions or Trade orders view, define the search criteria, and save the search (see Saving search views in FA Back reference for details).

title: Generate reports based on the saved search
body: Click the printer icon in the top-right corner of the view. In the Report window that opens, select the report and report options. In the Saved search field, choose the search you created in the previous step.

title: Generate reports based on the saved search
body: To schedule the report generation, click Add schedule and follow the steps in Schedule reports.

title: Mark transactions and trade orders as reported with tags
body: You can automatically maintain an up-to-date list of transactions or trade orders that need to be reported and those that have already been reported. For example, this is convenient if you send out transaction or trade order confirmations to your clients. To set up this feature, you need to create tags, for example, "Confirmation sent" and "Confirmation pending". Then, set up the system to generate reports for the pending transactions or trade orders and replace the tag after reports are ready.

title: Mark transactions and trade orders as reported with tags
body: Create tags for transactions and trade orders in Preference view. For example, you can create a tag called "Confirmation pending" for transactions and trade orders that are awaiting report generation and a tag called "Confirmation sent" for transactions and trade orders that have already been reported. For detailed instructions on creating tags, see Preference - Tags.

title: Mark transactions and trade orders as reported with tags
body: Create two saved searches in the Transactions or Trade orders view for the transactions or trade orders and use the tags you just created as a search filter. All new transactions or trade orders with the specified tag are added to this view. To learn how to save search views, see Saving search views.

title: Mark transactions and trade orders as reported with tags
body: Click the printer icon in the top-right corner of the view for pending transaction or trade orders to create a new report.

title: Mark transactions and trade orders as reported with tags
body: Select the search view you saved in the Saved search field and add the tag to be automatically applied after the report is generated in the Transaction tags or Trade order tags field. For example, you can enter the "Confirmation sent" tag here.

title: Mark transactions and trade orders as reported with tags
body: After you complete these steps, generating the report automatically applies the new tag to transactions or trade orders for which reports have been sent out.

title: Compliance
body: Compliance

title: You can
body: Track your investments through various set limits or models.

title: You can
body: Monitor if the value of the portfolio has dropped more than 10%.

title: You can
body: Export contact data out of the system.

title: You can
body: Take out reports Ex-ante costs and charges and Ex-post costs and charges, based on the expense classification you made.

title: You can
body: Audit the changes in the system data.

title: You can
body: Update contact information via integration with Roaring.

title: Related links

title: Update contact information with Roaring
body: You can get up-to-date contact information from local authorities in Finland and Sweden by using the Roaring integration.

title: Prerequisites
body: You need an agreement with Roaring to use the integration. Roaring can guide you through getting the necessary agreements and permits.

title: Prerequisites
body: The contacts whose information you want to fetch must have their social security numbers stored as the Contact ID in FA Back.

title: Setting up
body: To set up the Roaring connection, see Set up Roaring connection.

title: Running contact information updates
body: To update contact information using the Roaring integration, go to the Contacts view, search for the contacts whose information you want to update, and select Roaring.io → Update from Finnish population register or Roaring.io → Update from Swedish population register at the bottom of the view.

title: Running contact information updates
body: The following fields in the Contact window are updated:

title: Running contact information updates
body: Name

title: Running contact information updates
body: Address

title: Running contact information updates
body: The following fields are updated only from the Swedish population register:

title: Running contact information updates
body: Tag group Deregistration is updated with the official reason code if the contact has been removed from the population register. The reason codes are listed on the Roaring website.

title: Running contact information updates
body: Key figure Death date is updated with the death date of a deceased person. This is accompanied by the Deregistration tag AV.

title: Running contact information updates
body: Key figure Guardian is updated with the social security number of the contact's legal guardian and the date of validity.

title: Related links
body: Communications in FA Back reference

title: Documents
body: You can store documents and links in the FA system by linking them to a contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order. You can then send the documents to your clients via email. FA also allows you to send documents to be signed by your client, and you can monitor the signing process.

title: Manage documents
body: FA allows you to store and link documents related to contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, and trade orders. You can store documents by uploading them as files or linking them from an external source. This topic describes how you can search and manage documents on the level of individual contacts, portfolios, securities, transactions, or trade orders. To manage all documents in the FA system, see Administering documents in FA Admin guide.

title: Manage documents
body: When uploading documents, the supported file types are: PDF, DOC, DOCX, ODT, XLS, XLSX, PPT, PPTX, ODP, ODS, TXT, CSV, XML, PNG, JPG, RTF, and MP3.

title: Upload documents
body: You can add new documents in the Document tab of the Contact, Portfolio, Security, Transaction, or Trade order window, or in the Documents section of Overview or customer details. You can upload documents as files from your computer or link them from external sources (for linking documents, see Link external documents).

title: Upload documents
body: To add documents, do the following:

title: Upload documents
body: Open the contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order where you want to add documents and go to the Documents tab or section.

title: Upload documents
body: Click Upload file and select the documents from your computer.

title: Upload documents
body: The documents are added to the list. To search the documents, see Search documents.

title: Link external documents
body: You can also add documents as links to external sources such as URL addresses or your internal document library. Linked documents are listed the same way as documents in the system, but they have the icon and the extension ".link".

title: Link external documents
body: To upload a linked document, do the following:

title: Link external documents
body: Open the contact, portfolio, security, transaction, or trade order where you want to add documents and go to the Documents tab or section.

title: Link external documents
body: Click Upload link, and fill in the fields:

title: Link external documents
body: Document name. Name shown in the document list.

title: Link external documents
body: Link to document. URL of the document. The link can point to, for example, a document stored online or in your internal document library.

title: Link external documents
body: Click Save.

title: Link external documents
body: The document is now linked to the system. If you need to edit a link, remove it and add it again. To search the documents, see Search documents.

title: Download documents
body: To download a document, right-click it and select Download document. The document is downloaded to your computer.

title: Modify documents
body: You can modify the name, tags or folder location of a document:

title: Modify documents
body: Right-click the document and select Modify document.

title: Modify documents
body: Modify the document information:

title: Modify documents
body: Rename. Change the document name or folder. You can use this field to move the document into or out of a sub-folder (you can't directly edit the document file path). For example, you can rename a document "Contracts/NewContract.pdf" to place it into a sub-folder called "Contracts". To move the document back into the parent folder from "Contracts", you can rename the document "../NewContract.pdf". You can't delete sub-folders.

title: Modify documents
body: Document tags. Change the document tags.

title: Modify documents
body: Click Save.

title: Modify documents
body: The document information is now modified.

title: Delete documents
body: To delete a document, do the following:

title: Delete documents
body: Right-click the document and select Delete document.

title: Delete documents
body: Click Yes.

title: Delete documents
body: The document is deleted and the list is updated.

title: Search documents
body: You can find uploaded or linked documents in the Documents tab of the corresponding window. You can also search documents in the Documents section of Overview for contacts and portfolios, or by opening a customer in the Customers view. You can search for documents by name, date, time, modifier, and tags.

title: Search documents
body: The documents are listed in a table that shows the document name, the document type as an icon, the date, time, and user who last modified the document, and the document tags. To see documents in sub-folders when searching, tick the checkbox next to the tree structure icon . You can enable this, for example, to see portfolio and transaction documents when viewing a contact. If a document folder has separate sub-folders, you can select them in a drop-down menu.

title: System security measures
body: The following measures prevent users from uploading harmful documents into the system:

title: System security measures
body: Maximum document size. To define the maximum file size users can upload, see Preference - Administration in FA Back reference. For example, if a typical file size is 10 MB, you can reject files larger than 25 MB.

title: System security measures
body: Limit document upload frequency. To control how many documents a user can upload and how frequently (for example, a user can upload 1 new document every 10 seconds), see Preference - Administration in FA Back reference. If the system detects suspiciously frequent document uploads from a single user, the user is prohibited from uploading documents for some time.
