body: Change the width by dragging the boundary.

title: Adjust the view
body: Sort by clicking the column name.

title: Adjust the view
body: Adjust table row density ().

title: Adjust the view
body: Filter the table based on column content ().

title: Adjust the view
body: Search the table with the search fields at the top of the view.

title: Adjust the view
body: Click and enter the view name. If you used the search fields at the top and want to save them, make sure the checkbox Save current search criteria is ticked.

title: Adjust the view
body: Click Save.

title: Adjust the view
body: The adjustments are saved as a view. You can now:

title: Adjust the view
body: Set a saved view as the default. To do this, click the Saved views field or , and then click the star icon next to the saved view.

title: Adjust the view
body: Open a saved view, work with it and make changes to it, and then use to restore the view to its previously saved settings.

title: Adjust the view
body: Clear the saved view and return to the initial system view (click in the Saved views field).

title: Adjust the view
body: Rename or delete saved views (click to open the saved views sidepane).

title: Audit search results
body: The available columns are:

title: Audit search results
body: Action

title: Audit search results
body: The type of action performed by the user, such as logging in, creating a portfolio, generating a report, or calculating NAV.

title: Audit search results
body: Application

title: Audit search results
body: FA app where the action was performed.

title: Audit search results
body: Attachment

title: Audit search results
body: Attachment with the log details. You can download the attachment as a TXT file by clicking or preview the attachment in the side pane by clicking .

title: Audit search results
body: Component ID

title: Audit search results
body: The system component where the action was performed.

title: Audit search results
body: Event ID

title: Audit search results
body: Reference of the event that generated the log.

title: Audit search results
body: Log level

title: Audit search results
body: The log levels to view: "info", "warn" or "error".

title: Audit search results
body: Log time

title: Audit search results
body: The date and time of the user action.

title: Audit search results
body: Message

title: Audit search results
body: Log message describing the user action. You can expand long messages by clicking and Expand all messages.

title: Audit search results
body: IP address

title: Audit search results
body: User's IP address.

title: Audit search results
body: View

title: Audit search results
body: The application view where the action was performed.

title: Audit search results
body: Source

title: Audit search results
body: The log table where the action was recorded. Audit user log records user actions. Audit system log records system operations. For details, see Track what customer information has been viewed or exported in FA Back reference.

title: Audit search results
body: Target ID

title: Audit search results
body: The ID of the object the user viewed, modified, or created – for example, portfolio ID or transaction ID.

title: Audit search results
body: Target type

title: Audit search results
body: The type of object the user viewed, modified, or created – for example, portfolio or transaction.

title: Audit search results
body: User

title: Audit search results
body: User ID.

title: User management view
body: The User management view allows you to manage FA Platform users and their access rights to applications. The following sections describe what viewing options you have, how to manage users, how to assign user roles, how to manage user authentication, and how to manage user and account information.

title: Viewing options
body: You can:

title: Viewing options
body: Search for users by their user ID, first name, last name, and email (fields at the top).

title: Viewing options
body: Refresh the table content by clicking at the top right.

title: Viewing options
body: Export the user information as an XLSX file.

title: Viewing options
body: For the whole table, click Export → Download as XLSX.

title: Viewing options
body: For specific rows, select users and click Export → Download as XLSX.

title: Viewing options
body: Adjust the table (see Adjust the view).

title: Adjust the view
body: You can adjust the table layout and specify the search criteria and then save these modifications for later:

title: Adjust the view
body: Make your adjustments. You can:

title: Adjust the view
body: Adjust columns.

title: Adjust the view
body: Show or hide columns ().

title: Adjust the view
body: Reorder by dragging and dropping.

title: Adjust the view
body: Change the width by dragging the boundary.

title: Adjust the view
body: Sort by clicking the column name.

title: Adjust the view
body: Adjust table row density ().

title: Adjust the view
body: Filter the table based on column content ().

title: Adjust the view
body: Search the table with the search fields at the top of the view.

title: Adjust the view
body: Click and enter the view name. If you used the search fields at the top and want to save them, make sure the checkbox Save current search criteria is ticked.

title: Adjust the view
body: Click Save.

title: Adjust the view
body: The adjustments are saved as a view. You can now:

title: Adjust the view

title: Adjust the view
body: Open a saved view, work with it and make changes to it, and then use to restore the view to its previously saved settings.

title: Adjust the view
body: Clear the saved view and return to the initial system view (click in the Saved views field).

title: Adjust the view
body: Rename or delete saved views (click to open the saved views sidepane).

title: Manage users and roles
body: You can add new users in the system and deactivate or delete existing users.

title: Add a user
body: To create a user account:

title: Add a user
body: Click Add user at the top-right corner and fill in the user information:

title: Add a user
body: The User ID used as a username at login and Email (required fields).

title: Add a user
body: Linked contact to set up access to client data or access to FA Front access with the external identity provider.

title: Add a user
body: Other fields if needed. See User details and account information for details.

title: Add a user
body: Click Edit user roles in the User details pane and choose which apps your user can access and with what roles.

title: Add a user
body: To access an app, a user needs a role for it – a user without any roles can't access any application.

title: Add a user
body: Let the user know about their credentials and how to get a password.

title: Add a user
body: Send them the user ID – FA platform doesn't send this information automatically.

title: Add a user
body: Instruct the user to request a password reset link by clicking Forgot password on the login page.

title: Deactivate a user
body: If a user doesn't need to access the platform anymore, we recommend deactivating their account rather than deleting it – this maintains the user's history while preventing them from accessing FA.

title: Deactivate a user
body: To change the status for multiple users, choose the users in the table and click . To change the status for one user, click in the User details pane. You can see the user's status in the table:

title: Deactivate a user
body: Active – The user can log in to the FA platform.

title: Deactivate a user
body: Inactive – The user can't log in to the FA platform.

title: Delete a user
body: Deleting a user removes all user information from the system. A deleted user can’t log in. If you just want to disable a user and prevent them from logging in, consider deactivating the user instead of deleting the account. To delete a user, click in the User details pane.

title: Assign user roles
body: The Roles block in the User details pane shows the roles assigned to the user. Roles determine:

title: Assign user roles
body: The app the user can access. To access an app, the user needs at least one role within that app. For example, if a user has a right in FA Back, the user is allowed to access FA Back.

title: Assign user roles
body: The access rights within the app. For example, FA Back roles determine access rights through permission and FA Front roles determine access rights through the views defined for the role.

title: Assign user roles
body: To add or remove the user’s roles, click Edit user roles at the top of the User details pane.

title: Manage authentication
body: You can manage user authentication using the following options:

title: Password reset
body: You can force the user to reset their password on next login. To force a password reset for multiple users, choose the users in the table and click . To force password reset for a selected user, click in the User details pane, choose Force password reset on next login and save the changes.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Two-factor authentication is a login option that requires entering a verification code in addition to the basic credentials (user ID and password). You can check two-factor authentication status in the User details pane:

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Disabled – Two-factor authentication is turned off.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Enabled – Two-factor authentication is turned on. The user has logged in and completed the mobile authenticator setup.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Pending – Two-factor authentication is turned on. You chose “Enable two-factor authentication on next login”, but the user didn’t yet log in to complete the setup.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: To manage two-factor authentication, use the buttons (available depending on the two-factor authentication status):

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Enable two-factor authentication

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Enable two-factor authentication on the next login for the user.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Cancel two-factor authentication

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Cancel two-factor authentication request that is pending.

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Disable two-factor authentication

title: Two-factor authentication
body: Disable two-factor authentication for the user.

title: Brute force detection
body: FA Platform uses brute force detection to identify attempts to guess a user’s password. Brute force detection temporarily disables the user's account after a certain number and frequency of login failures. The user account is disabled for one minute if:

title: Brute force detection
body: The user enters incorrect credentials twice within a second. This means that someone tries to guess the password programmatically.

title: Brute force detection
body: The user fails to enter correct credentials 5 times. After the account is disabled, every unsuccessful attempt increases the lock by one minute, up to one hour.

title: Brute force detection
body: To check if a user account is disabled by the brute force detection, open the User details pane and go to the Brute force detection section. It includes the following information:

title: Brute force detection
body: Status

title: Brute force detection
body: Brute force detection status of the user account: Blocked (deactivated by brute force detection), or Unblocked (active). A user blocked by brute force detection has to wait for up to 1 hour (depending on the number of unsuccessful login attempts) for the account to be unblocked.

title: Brute force detection
body: Total login attempts

title: Brute force detection
body: The number of failed login attempts.

title: Brute force detection
body: Last attempt

title: Brute force detection
body: The date and time of the last login attempt.

title: Brute force detection
body: IP address

title: Brute force detection
body: The IP address from which the last login attempt was made.

title: Brute force detection
body: To activate a blocked user account, choose Unblock and activate. Once unblocked, your user can log in again without waiting for the system to unblock the user after a certain time.

title: User details and account information
body: You can view or edit a user's information by clicking on them in the table (the User details sidepane opens). The following user information is available:

title: User account information
body: User ID (required)

title: User account information
body: A unique user ID for logging in to FA and log the user's activities.

title: User account information
body: Email (required)

title: User account information
body: The user’s email to send a password reset link to the user, if the user clicks Forgot password on the login page.

title: User account information
body: First name, Last name

title: User account information
body: The user’s first and last name.

title: User account information
body: Linked contact

title: User account information
body: The corresponding contact in FA Back. Linked contact is needed to:

title: User account information
body: Grant access only to certain customers and portfolios (see the Set up limited visibility for one user and Set up limited visibility for many users sections in the FA Admin guide).

title: User account information
body: Allow online end users to view their own investments in FA Front. A user that has a linked contact has access to the investment information associated with this contact.

title: User account information
body: Linked contact external ID

title: User account information
body: The user’s external ID received from the external identity provider when the user logs in to FA Front. External ID is used to find a matching contact for the user. If you see this field, this means that FA failed to link a contact to the user. For example, there is no contact with such an ID or there are several contacts with this ID stored in FA. In this case, you can add a contact manually in the Linked contact field.

title: User account information
body: Status

title: User account information
body: The user account status: active (the user can log in to FA) or inactive (the user can't log in to the system). See Assign user roles for details.

title: Sessions
body: The Sessions block shows a list of currently active sessions for the user. For example, the same user might have logged in with different browsers, having multiple sessions open at the same time. The list shows:

title: Sessions
body: Application

title: Sessions
body: The apps where the user is logged in within the session. For example, the user might have FA Back and FA Front open in different tabs in the same browser, accessing both applications with a single login and a single session.

title: Sessions
body: Last access

title: Sessions
body: The date and time the user accessed an app within the session. If the user accesses only one app, this shows the time they logged in, or if your user accesses multiple apps, this shows the time the user last opened a new app.

title: Sessions
body: IP address

title: Sessions
body: Shows the IP address the user is logged in from.

title: Sessions
body: You can log the user out of all sessions by clicking Log out user from all sessions. The user will be able to use FA for a short time until their authentication expires, then they will get a "communication problem" and will be taken to the login page.

title: Last logins
body: The Last logins block shows date and time of the five last user logins.

title: Related links
body: Managing users in FA Admin guide

title: Related links
body: Authentication in FA Admin guide

title: Rights window
body: The Rights window lets you view and modify what rights are included in the role. To open the Rights window, click in the Role pane on the right in the Role management view.

title: Rights window
body: You can filter and search user rights by application, role, or description. The list of user rights shows the name of each right in the system, its description and the permissions it provides, and if the right is compatible with limited visibility. A green checkmark in the Limited visibility column indicates that the right can be used with the limited visibility functionality.

title: Analyze profit and loss
body: PnL view let you track key indicators, such as market value, profit, exposure, and so on. You can fine-tune the table to show the information you need.

title: Set up the table
body: To view the position data, set up the table – choose what positions, adjust the table rows and columns.

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Choose the port to analyze and set the currency at the top of the view:

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Portfolio group

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Portfolio group to view. Portfolio groups are configured in FA Back.

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Positions

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Positions to view:

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: All – Settled and unsettled positions.

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Settled only – Only settled positions.

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: With pending orders – Positions from pending trade orders, as well as settled and unsettled positions.

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Currency

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: The currency to view position data.

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Portfolio – Portfolio currency.

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: <Currency code> – A currency from the list.

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: Include subportfolios

title: 1. Choose the portfolios to view
body: An option to show subportfolio positions as a part of the parent portfolio. Subportfolio positions are summed up with the parent portfolio positions. For including the subportfolios as individual positions, include the subportfolios separately in the portfolio group in FA Back.

title: 2. Select columns
body: Click Columns on the right and select the columns from Portfolio details, Security details and Position details. For the full list of columns, see Position data in the PnL view.

title: 3. Group position rows
body: You can group the positions rows – for example, on the screenshot above positions are grouped by portfolio, security types within the portfolio, and security currency. To set the grouping, drag the column name from the Columns pane on the right to the grouping row above the table.

title: 4. Filter and sort
body: To filter the rows in the table, click Filters on the right and select the filtering parameter. For example, you can filter out positions in a certain currency. You can also filter the values by clicking in the column header.

title: 4. Filter and sort
body: To sort the values from largest to smallest and vice versa, click the column header. You can also click three dots in the column header and choose the sorting option.

title: Rebalance portfolios against strategy in FA Invest
body: Strategy rebalancing makes sure your portfolio follows allocation shares defined in the strategy. If an asset type is below or above the target, the system suggests buys or sells to increase the portfolio positions proportionally. If an asset type is missing from the portfolio (for example, the strategy requires 10% Finnish stocks but the portfolio doesn't have any), the system suggests equally-sized trade orders for each security in the missing asset type from your buy list.

title: Rebalance portfolios against strategy in FA Invest
body: Strategy rebalancing doesn't adjust holdings within the asset type. For example, if Finnish holdings in the portfolio are represented by one security, rebalancing considers this sufficient. It doesn't suggest sells to buy other Finnish stocks from the buy list.

title: Rebalance portfolios against strategy in FA Invest
body: Strategy rebalancing works only for equity portfolios. It should not be used with funds and ETFs that are allocated to several asset types (for example, a fund security can be allocated as 70% US and 30% Canada).

title: Settings for strategy rebalancing
body: Make sure you have a strategy and buy list defined in FA Back:

title: Settings for strategy rebalancing
body: To learn more about defining a strategy, see Strategy

title: Settings for strategy rebalancing

title: Set up the table and define rebalance options

title: Set up the table and define rebalance options
body: Choose the positions you want to rebalance and click the Rebalance button. You can see the suggested values in the Target values section.

title: Rebalance options
body: Buy with

title: Rebalance options
body: Cash to use for buys:

title: Rebalance options
body: Current cash only. With this option, you can align the portfolio with the model in two rounds. First, the system sells the excess positions and buys with the current cash. After executing the sells and acquiring cash, the second round buys more positions with the newly available cash to rebalance the portfolio fully.

title: Rebalance options
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance options
body: Buy trade orders reduce the current cash.

title: Rebalance options
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance options
body: Cash from sells only. With this option, you can sell a portfolio position that is above the target and buy a position that is below the target with the cash you expect to get from selling. You can also rebalance one position and swap it for another without rebalancing your entire portfolio. Cash from suggested sells is estimated based on the latest market prices.

title: Rebalance options
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you have enough cash to complete the buys.

title: Rebalance options
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance options
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance options
body: Current cash and cash from sells. With this option, you can align the portfolio with the model in one go. Cash from suggested sells is estimated based on the latest prices.

title: Rebalance options
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you settle the trades promptly and have enough cash to complete the buys. To mitigate the risk, you can set a limit on the cash from sells to use for buys during a full rebalance. For example, instead of counting sell values at 100%, you can count them at 95%. If the prices drop between rebalancing and executing sales, you'll likely still have enough cash to complete your buys. See Preference - Portfolios for details.

title: Rebalance options
body: Existing outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") affect rebalancing in the following way:

title: Rebalance options
body: Buy trade orders reduce the current cash.

title: Rebalance options
body: Outstanding trade orders with the same type are taken into account when the system suggests buys and sells. For example, if you should buy a security but you already have a buy trade order for it, the trade amount of the outstanding order is subtracted from the suggested order.

title: Rebalance options
body: Current cash, cash from sells and from orders. With this option, you can align the portfolio at once, considering the effect of outstanding orders. Before rebalancing, the system calculates expected positions. It sells any expected excess positions and buys with the cash expected to be available after executing these orders.Cash from suggested sells and outstanding trade orders (all statuses except "Open") is estimated based on the latest prices.

title: Rebalance options
body: This method requires careful trade order management to ensure you have enough cash to complete the buys.

title: Rebalance options
body: Use cash from accounts

title: Rebalance options
body: Accounts to use for buys if you select to buy with extra cash in the portfolio. This option allows you to keep your portfolio fully invested and exclude certain accounts (for example, accrued fee accounts) from rebalancing.

title: Rebalance options
body: "All accounts" – Use cash on all accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance options
body: "Cash accounts" – Use cash on the accounts marked as "cash accounts" in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab.

title: Rebalance options
body: "Cash and credit accounts" – Use cash on cash and credit accounts. You can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance options
body: "Default account only" – Use cash on the portfolio's default account – the first account in the list in the Portfolio window, Accounts tab. If this account is a credit account, you can choose to use available credit or repay the used credit (see the Use portfolio credit field below).

title: Rebalance options
body: Filter out small trade orders based on

title: Rebalance options
body: The minimum size for the trade orders that rebalancing should create. The size restrictions don't apply if you sell an entire position away from the portfolio (see Selling an entire position). Set the minimum difference between the portfolio position and the model as:

title: Rebalance options
body: "Diff %pt" – The difference in percentage points.

title: Rebalance options
body: "Diff %" – The relative difference in percentage.

title: Rebalance options
body: "Trade amount" – The minimum trade amount in portfolio currency. Alternatively, you can define a Minimum trade amount for each of your securities in FA Back (see Security window).

title: Rebalance options
body: "Model min/max share" – The difference defined with the minimum and maximum thresholds in the model. Trade orders are created only if the position deviates outside of the minimum and maximum thresholds. The minimum trade amount for each trade order is calculated as follows:

title: Rebalance options
body: For "buy": ( target share - min share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance options
body: For "sell": ( max share - target share ) * portfolio value

title: Rebalance options
body: Positions that don't have the thresholds specified in the model are rebalanced without filtering when "Position is within min/max share" is selected.

title: Rebalance options
body: Apply fees to trade orders

title: Rebalance options
body: An option to include fees in buy and sell trade orders. Fees are taken into account when the system calculates how much you can buy and how much cash you get from sells. This allows you to estimate the effects of upcoming transaction fees more accurately. Fees are also saved in the Fees field for each trade order.

title: Rebalance options
body: "No fees" – Don't include fees in trade orders.

title: Rebalance options
body: "Portfolio-specific fees" – Include a transaction fee defined for the portfolio in FA Back (Portfolio window, Fees tab).

title: Rebalance options
body: "Fixed fees" – Include a fee defined as a percentage in the field available next to the selection.

title: Adjust target values
body: If needed, you can adjust the target values further by adding positions or editing values:

title: Adjust target values
body: To add a position in the list, click Add position. Select the security and portfolio and click Add. Remember that yo can add all securities that are included in the strategy buy list by selecting Include all positions from model .

title: Adjust target values
body: To exclude some positions from rebalancing, select the rows and click Exclude positions.

title: Adjust target values
body: To adjust target values one by one, edit the Target values section of the table.

title: Adjust target values
body: To adjust several position values, select the asset type positions and click Edit positions. Fill in the fields:

title: Adjust target values
body: Column

title: Adjust target values
body: The value you want to adjust.

title: Adjust target values
body: Value

title: Adjust target values
body: The adjustment value.

title: Adjust target values
body: Method

title: Adjust target values
body: The option to choose how the adjustment value is applied to the selected positions:

title: Adjust target values
body: "Apply to all rows" – Apply the value to each position, instead of the existing value.

title: Adjust target values
body: "Distribute the value evenly" – Divide the value equally between positions. For example, you can distribute the market value of 1000€ between 5 positions, which will add 200€ to each of them.

title: Adjust target values
body: "Distribute based on current position" – Allocate the adjustment proportionally to selected positions based on the number of units.

title: Adjust target values
body: "Distribute based on model position" – Allocate the adjustment proportionally to selected positions based on the model shares.

title: Adjust target values
body: "Distribute based on portfolio market value" – Allocate the adjustment proportionally to selected positions based on the current market value.

title: Check and create suggested trade orders
body: Once you are satisfied with the target values you see, you can proceed to trade order preview.

title: Check and create suggested trade orders

body: Click Preview.

title: Check and create suggested trade orders

title: Check and create suggested trade orders
body: Check limits to see if the trade orders are within the portfolio limits.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Name (ENG) Description

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Amount Amount (p) Amount (p, o) Amount (p, t) Shows the amount of the security in the portfolio based on the transaction date (amount), when all Executable trade orders would have been executed (p, o), when all accepted non-settled (i.e. settlement date later than today or no settlement date at all) transactions would have been settled (p, t) or when all Executable trade orders and accepted non-settled transactions would have been executed and settled (p). For accounts and cash balance, the amount shows the account balance based on transaction date, amount (p, o) the cash balance after Executable trade orders that deduct cash have been executed, amount (p, t) the currently settled cash balance (excluding non-settled transactions, i.e. transactions that have a settlement date in the future), and amount (p) the combination of the two above.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Accr. int. Accr. int (c) Shows the accrued interest for your position in portfolio currency or in security currency (c), when fixing information is defined in the security's Security window. For a new position, the accrued interest is the accrued interest bought within the buy transaction until the settlement date of the buy, after which the accrued interest is calculated with the defined coupon information. Also shows the accrued interest for accounts. For accounts, the accrued interest is calculated day-by-day and is shown as a total amount.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Accrual Accrual (c) Shows your positions’ accrued income in portfolio currency or in security currency (c), when your mutual fund position's market price contains the accrued income element. The value in the accrual field indicates how much accrued income in security currency was included in that day’s market price. Accrual is calculated based on your fund security’s accrual (maintained in security’s market data) as Accrual = amount x accrual. Accrual is taken into account account in other position values as follows: Purchase value excludes paid accrual recorded to transactions.Market value excludes position’s accrual.Market value (d) includes position’s accrual.Purchase unit price and Market unit price include accrual.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Change Change (o) Change % Change % (o) Shows the difference between the Purchase value and Market value columns: how much the purchase value has changed. Also available as the change between the purchase price and market price columns with the original purchase price (o), in percentage (%) or in percentage with the original purchase price (% (o)).

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Total commitment Total commitment (c) Remaining commitment Remaining commitment (c) Shows the total commitment of the position, based on transaction types that increase commitment in portfolio currency or in security currency (c), or the remaining commitment of the position, based on transaction types that either increase or reduce commitment in portfolio currency or in security currency (c). Commitments are relevant for example for private equity investments.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Currency (Price) Currency Shows the currency defined for the security or currency exposure. The latter column shows the currency the instrument is exposed to: if the security has an underlay, and the underlay is a currency, the code of the underlying security is shown, otherwise the currency of the underlying security is shown. If the security doesn't have an underlay, and if the security is a currency, the code of the security is shown, otherwise the currency of the security is shown.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Days Shows the position's age in the portfolio, calculated from the the date of the oldest open purchase lot.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Exposure Shows your position's market exposure. Exposure is calculated daily as Exposure = (amount x market unit price + accrued interest) / market FX rate. If your security has delta (maintained in security’s market data), exposure is multiplied by delta. Note that if delta is not found on the latest market data observation relative to the valuation date, delta is assumed to be 1 (i.e. delta has no effect on exposure). For example, if security has price on the valuation date of 2020-01-30, but no delta is recorded on that date, delta is assumed to be 1. Even if delta is found on 2020-01-29, that delta is not used, since it was not found on the same date as the latest price. If your security is linked to another security, exposure is calculated as Exposure = amount x linked security’s market unit price in pf currency x block size.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Holding % Shows the share of position’s amount out of the total outstanding amount defined in the security, indicating how large of a share does the portfolio hold of the security.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: MPrice MPrice (c) Shows the current market unit price of the security in the portfolio currency or market price in currency (c). The date in parentheses tells the date of the market unit price: if there is no date after the market unit price, the price observation is dated for the viewing date (chosen above the portfolio contents). If no market price is defined for a security, this columns shows a line.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: MPrice daily change Shows the percentage change between the selected date's market price compared to the previous market price found.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Market date Shows the date of the market price utilized as the market unit price and in calculating the market value, if the utilized market price is not the selected day's price.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Market val. Shows the total market price of the security or the account balance in the portfolio currency, based on the latest market price or the exchange rate of the account currency. If no market price is defined for a security, the market price is calculated with the unit purchase price. Market value on the Overview excludes accrual on your fund positions and accrued interests on your bond positions.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Market value (d) Shows the "dirty" market value, or a proper market value for your bonds and futures: this column shows a sum of market value + accrued interest for your bond positions, the P/L for your future positions, sum of market value + accrual for your fund positions, and market value for all other types of instruments.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Market FX rate Shows the exchange rate used to calculate the market value of the position in portfolio currency.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Orders Orders (all) Shows the effect the executable trade orders (orders) or executable and open trade orders (all) will have on the position's amount when executed. E.g. an executable sell trade order in the portfolio with the amount 100 will show as -100 in the columns.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Pledged Shows if the position is pledged. "Yes" indicates the position or part of it is pledged. "No" indicates the position is unpledged. Pledged positions are unavailable for trading.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: PP / unit PP/u (c) PP/u (o) PP/u (oc) PP/u (desc.) Shows the purchase unit price of the security in the portfolio currency: the unit price the security was purchased with. Also available purchase unit price in currency (c), with the original price (o), with the original price in currency (oc) or with all available decimals (desc.). For accounts, the purchase unit price tells the exchange rate of currency of the account against the portfolio currency.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: PPc/u PPc/u (c) Shows the purchase unit price without cost or purchase unit price without cost in currency (c).

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Purchase value Shows the total purchase value of the security or the account balance in the portfolio currency. Purchase value on the Overview excludes paid accrual on your fund positions and paid accrued interests on your bond positions.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Purchase value without cost Shows the total purchase value of the security or the account balance in the portfolio currency without costs.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Purch. val (o) Shows the purchase value calculated with original price.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Security This column divides the contents of the portfolio into securities and accounts. The securities are divided under subtitles based on the security types configured in the system, and the accounts section shows all the accounts added to the portfolio. The total of the securities and accounts are calculated, and you can find them on the rows Securities total and Accounts total . There are also a Portfolio total calculations available.

title: Available columns for positions listings
body: Share % Shows percentage share of the position's market value from portfolio's total market value.

title: Key figures
body: Key figure Description

title: Key figures
body: Collateral value The collateral value of a portfolio position, calculated by multiplying the market value and collateral ratio of the security.

title: Key figures
body: Available credit The amount of portfolio credit available for the client to use.

title: Key figures
body: Used credit The amount of portfolio credit already used by the client.

title: Key figures
body: Portfolio credit The total amount of portfolio credit made available to the client.

To import representative tag values, add them after ###: Add standalone tags as <representative's contact ID>###<tag name 1>#<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Standalone1#Standalone2Add single-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name 1>#<group name>-<tag name 2>. For example: 258258###Permission-View#Relationship type-AdvisorAdd multi-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>#<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission for trade orders:Make#Permission for trade orders:ModifyTo import multiple types of tags simultaneously, separate the tags with #. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Employee:Finance#Employee:Accounting#Relationship type-Advisor#Standalone1#Standalone2

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 17 p.contact No Other contacts Portfolio's other contacts. Contact IDs as a comma-separated list. To import representative tag values, add them after ###: Add standalone tags as <representative's contact ID>###<tag name 1>#<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Standalone1#Standalone2Add single-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name 1>#<group name>-<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Relationship type-AdvisorAdd multi-select group tags as <representative's contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>#<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Permission for trade orders:Make#Permission for trade orders:ModifyTo import multiple types of tags simultaneously, separate the tags with #. For example: 04012000###Permission-View#Employee:Finance#Employee:Accounting#Relationship type-Advisor#Standalone1#Standalone2

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 18 Default account Not used.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 19 p.accounts No Accounts  A colon-separated (:) list of the portfolio accounts. To add accounts to a portfolio, use the following syntax: <Account no.>,<Currency with currency code>,<Name>,<Visibility as 0=not visible 1=visible>,<Shared as 0=not shared 1=shared>,<Priority as integer>;<BIC code>,<Mandate>,<Secondary account number>,<Category>,<Account type as 0=not cash, 1=cash, 2=credit>,<Hide if zero as 0=don’t hide, 1=hide>,<Tags separated with #>,<Issuer with contact ID>,<Calendar with the calendar code>,<Fixing as a number>,<Base instrument with the security code>,<Spread as a number>,<Exclude balance as 0=don't exclude, 1=exclude>,<Shared with all as 0=not shared, 1=shared>, <Shared to all parent portfolio's subportfolios as 0=not shared, 1=shared>, <Decimals for transactions as a number>, <Transaction type code>, <Offset days as an integer>, <Account status as 0=open, 1=closed>, <Account open date in the format yyyy-MM-dd>, <Account close date in the format yyyy-MM-dd>. For example, a list of two accounts: FI12 3456 78,EUR,Euro account,1,0,1,NDEAFIHHXXX,12345678,12345-678,Bank account,1,0,Client account#Status OK,,,,,,,,,,,,0,2017-03-15:234-321,USD,Dollar account,0,1,2,,,,,1,0,Client account#Status OK,,Act/360,0.2,LIBOR,1.5,0,0,0,4,1,2020-05-10,2023-04-09. The account currency (second in the syntax) is validated to be a valid currency in the system. Supported calendar codes: 1/130/360ISDA30/360 PSA30E+/36030E/36030E/360 ISDA30U/36030U/36030U/360 EOMAct/360Act/364Act/365 ActualAct/365.25Act/365FAct/365LAct/366Act/366.375Act/Act AFBAct/Act ICMAAct/Act ISDAAct/Act YearNL/365 You can use *** syntax to add new accounts for the portfolio while keeping the old ones, but this is not required. Without ***, old values are still preserved. For example: ***:<Account>:<Account>). To update the account number of an existing account, use the syntax "[old account no]new account no" in the first field of the account syntax. For example, if you want to update an account number from 1000 to 1010, define the account number in the syntax as [1000]1010. To keep the accounts unchanged, import an empty value in the field. Existing accounts cannot be removed using import.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 20 p.assetManagers No Asset managers Portfolio's asset managers. Contact IDs as a comma-separated list. To import representative tag values, add them after ###. Standalone tags are added as <contact ID>###<tag name>. For example: 04012000##parent.Single-select group tags are added as <contact ID>###<group name>-<tag name>. For example: 04012000##relative-parent.Multi-select group tags are added as a comma-separated list of values: <contact ID>###<group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>. For example: 04012000###Employee:Finance,Employee:Accounting.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 21 p.fees No Fees List of portfolio fees: <type>=<fee percent>. Types are: transaction, payment, withdrawal, management. E.g. transaction=2.3, management=1.5 You can use *** syntax to add fees to the portfolio and keep the existing ones. For example: ***,payment=3,withdrawal=3.9.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 22 p.startDate No Start date yyyy-MM-dd, portfolio start date

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 23 p.updateDate No Update date yyyy-MM-dd, portfolio update

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 24 p.ruleSet No Posting rule Code of the posting rule set. For multiple posting rule sets, use comma-separated list of posting rule set codes (available from FA 3.12 onward).

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 25 p.extPortfolioIdList No External IDs List of portfolio's external ID's. Use the following syntax <ext_id1=ext_name1>,<ext_id2=ext_name2> etc. If ext_id and ext_name combination for the same portfolio exist just use the existing one, otherwise create new one. If ext_id and ext_name combination exist but for a different portfolio, will show error message.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 26 p.benchmark No Benchmark Benchmark code (configured in the system) or in order to use portfolio specific benchmarks, use the following syntax <yyyy-MM-dd>,<security1 code>=<share1>,<security code2>=<share2>:<yyyy-MM-dd>,<security code3>=<share3> etc. You can use *** syntax to add new entries to the existing benchmark and keep the existing ones.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 27 p.country No Country Country code (configured in the system), if not given will use primary contact's tax country

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 28 p.juridical No Juridical Juridical form code (configured in the system), if not given will use primary contact's juridical form

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 29 p.emailAddresses No Email addresses Comma-separated list of email addresses. E.g. a@fasolutions.com, b@fasolutions.com

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 30 p.reportContacts No Report contacts Comma-separated list of contact IDs

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 31 p.closeMethod No Close method Define as a number: 0 = "Choose" 1 = "No change" 2 = "Depreciation" 3 = "Depreciation and refund" 4 = "Market value"

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 32 p.portfolioGroups No Portfolio groups Portfolio groups the portfolio is in. Specify the portfolio groups as a comma-separated list of group codes. You can use *** to add new groups to the portfolio while keeping the existing ones. For example: ***,<group code>.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 33 p.custody No Custody Contact for the custody (use the Contact ID to identify the custody).

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 34 p.bookEntry No Book entry String value for book entry account

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 35 p.modelPortfolio No Model portfolio Name of the model portfolio (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 36 p.costFormulas No Cost formula Comma-separated list of cost formula codes (configured in the system)

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 37 p.tags No Tags "The "Tags" field is a comma-separated list of tags that you can use to categorize your portfolios. To add a tag:  Standalone tags can be added by simply typing the tag name. For example, if you want to add a tag for a Fund and a tag for a ContractOK, you can add them like this: "Fund,ContractOK".Single-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>-<tag name>. For example, if you want to add a tag for an office location in Helsinki, you can add it like this: "office-Helsinki". If a portfolio already has a tag with the same group name, the new tag will replace the old one.Multi-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>, etc. For example, if you want to add tags for stocks and bonds in your Investments group, you can add them like this: "Investments:Stocks,Investments:Bonds". If a portfolio already has tags with the same group name, the new tags will be added to the existing ones. To remove a tag, use the syntax "---" followed by the tag name or tag group name. For example:  To remove a standalone tag for "Fund", you can use "---Fund".To remove a single-select group tag for "office-Helsinki", you can use "---office-Helsinki".To remove multi-select group tags for "Investments:Stocks" and "Investments:Bonds", you can use "---Investments:Stocks,---Investments:Bonds".

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 38 p.priceSource No Price source The method to determine the close market price for the securities in the portfolio. To use the prices from Security's Market data info tab, leave the field empty. To use the first available price from the price fields in the Security's Market data info tab (checking the column values in the order specified above), specify Default. To define a different priority of price source fields, enter a comma-separated list of columns in the order of priority. The values are: Manual, Close 1, Close 2, Close 3, Close 4, Close 5. You can use *** syntax to add new values in the list of price source fields and keep the existing ones. You can use three minuses (for example, ---Close 1) to remove a value.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 39 p.investmentPlan No Investment plan Portfolio-specific investment plan, use the following syntax <yyyy-MM-dd>,<security 1 code>=<share 1>,<security 2 code>=<share 2>:<yyyy-MM-dd>,<security 3 code>=<share 3> etc. If you want to import an investment plan with minimum and maximum shares, use the following syntax <yyyy-MM-dd>,<securityCode1>=<share1#minShare1#maxShare1>,<securityCode2>=<share2#minShare2#maxShare2>;<yyyy-MM-dd>;,<securityCode3>=<share3#minShare3#maxShare3> etc. Min and max shares are validated to align in relation to the target share (i.e. min smaller / max higher or equal to the target). You can use *** syntax to add new entries to the investment plan and keep the existing ones. For example: ***:2019-01-01,NOKIA=25#20#30,AMAZON=15#10#20.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 40 p.profileAttributes No Profile Portfolio-specific profile (configured in the system). Use the following syntax to import / update profile information: <key>=<value>:<type>#<key>=<value>:<type> etc. Note that importing checkbox fields requires you to use the type "boolean" and importing date fields requires you to use the type "date" in the syntax. Profile import allows you to add or modify profile values with a specific key - existing profile values are not replaced / removed unless you specifically include their key within the import syntax. To remove an individual value, use three minuses (---) in the field. If you edit the CSV file in MS Excel, you need to enter an apostrophe in the beginning of the column. For example: '---contact.profiling.totalAssets.To remove an individual value, use three minuses (---) in the field. If you edit the CSV file in MS Excel, you need to enter an apostrophe in the beginning of the column. For example: '---contact.profiling.totalAssets.To remove an individual value, use three minuses (---) in the field. If you edit the CSV file in MS Excel, you need to enter an apostrophe in the beginning of the column. For example: '---contact.profiling.totalAssets.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 41 p.strategy No Strategy Portfolio-specific strategy. Use the following syntax: <yyyy-MM-dd>,<assetTypeCode1#assetGroupCode1>=<share1#minShare1#maxShare1#FIXED>,<assetTypeCode2#assetGroupCode2>=<share2#minShare2#maxShare2>:<yyyy-MM-dd>,<assetTypeCode3#asset & GroupCode3>=<share3#minShare3#maxShare3> etc. For interpolation, specify "INTERPOLATION", calendar code, and two dates before the asset types. For example: INTERPOLATION=SatSun:<yyyy-MM-dd>,<assetTypeCode1#assetGroupCode1>=<share1#minShare1#maxShare1>,<assetTypeCode2#assetGroupCode2>=<share2#minShare2#maxShare2>, etc. For an asset type that is excluded from strategy analysis, specify "EXCLUDED" followed by three dots: <yyyy-MM-dd>,<assetTypeCode1#assetGroupCode1>=EXCLUDED... You can use *** syntax to add new entries to the strategy and keep the existing ones, for example: ***:2019-01-01,ASSET#MOD=100#0#100. If a portfolio has p.strategyFromPortfolio defined, you can’t import a strategy in the p.strategy field.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 42 p.parent No Parent portfolio Comma-separated list of parent portfolios' Portfolio IDs. The imported portfolio will be marked as the sub-portfolio to all the defined parent / main portfolios. You can use *** syntax to add new parent portfolios and keep the existing ones.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 43 p.accruedInterestValuation No Accrued interest Define as a number: 0 = "Transaction date" 1 = "Settlement date" If no value is filled in, the default value 0 "Transaction date" is used.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 44 p.keyFigures No Key figures Define the key figure code and individual observations as date-value pairs as a comma-separated list with the format <code>=<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>:<code>=<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,... For example, AAA=2009-01-01=1.9,2010-01-01=1.10:TAX=2007-01-01=1,2010-01-01=2 You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 45 p.aggregatingSubportfolios No Aggregation of subportfolios Define as a number: 0 = Sum up values1 = Recalculate values

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 46 p.locked No Locked Define as a number: 0 = Not locked (default)1 = Locked

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 47 p.postingsOnParent No Generate postings on parent level Define as a number: 0 = Generate postings on portfolio level1 = Generate postings on parent portfolio level

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 48 p.securityGroups No Security groups Security groups the portfolio is linked to. Specify the security groups as a comma-separated list of group codes. You can use *** to add new groups to the portfolio while keeping the existing ones. For example: ***, <group code>.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 49 p.twrDate No Import TWR date yyyy-MM-dd. The date until which Analytics+ should use precalculated TWR values.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 50 p.limitGroups No Limit groups Limit groups linked to the portfolio. Specify a comma-separated list of limit group codes. Note that you can import either limit groups or single limits in one file, but you can't import both simultaneously. You can use *** to add limit groups to the portfolio while keeping the existing limit groups and single limits. For example: ***,GROUPCODE1,GROUPCODE2.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 51 p.limits No Limits Single limits linked to the portfolio. Specify a comma-separated list of limit codes. Note that you can import either limit groups or single limits in one file, but you can't import both simultaneously. You can use *** to add new single limits to the portfolio while keeping the existing limit groups and single limits. For example: ***,MAX20,EURO40.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 52 p.strategyFromPortfolio No Strategy from portfolio Portfolio ID of the source portfolio to reuse the strategy from. A portfolio can have only one of the p.strategy or p.strategyFromPortfolio defined. Importing the portfolio ID in the p.strategyFromPortfolio field removes the strategy in the p.strategy field, it if exists.

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 53 p.pledged No Pledged Define as a number: 0 = Not pledged1 = Pledged Note that if the portfolio is already pledged, you can't unpledge it via the import functionality (see Pledge portfolios and positions in FA User guide).

title: FA Format for importing portfolios
body: 54 p.closeDate No Close date Portfolio close date. Define in the format yyyy-MM-dd.

body: 47 s.classType2 No Class 2 Describes a classification 2 for the security with a code. Code/name values for classifications are defined in the system.

body: 48 s.classType3 No Class 3 Describes a classification 3 for the security with a code. Code/name values for classifications are defined in the system.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 49 s.tags No Tags The "Tags" field is a comma-separated list of tags that you can use to categorize your securities. To add a tag: Standalone tags can be added by simply typing the tag name. For example, if you want to add a Fund tag and a New tag, you can add them like this: "Fund,New".Single-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>-<tag name>. For example, if you want to add a tag for an office location in Helsinki, you can add it like this: "office-Helsinki". If a security already has a tag with the same group name, the new tag will replace the old one.Multi-select group tags should be added in the format <group name>:<tag name 1>,<group name>:<tag name 2>, etc. For example, if you want to add tags to your Campaign group, you can add them like this: "Campaign:EarlyBird,Campaign:Friends". If a security already has tags with the same group name, the new tags will be added to the existing ones. To remove a tag, use the syntax "---" followed by the tag name or tag group name. For example: To remove a standalone tag for "Fund", you can use "---Fund".To remove a single-select group tag for "office-Helsinki", you can use "---office-Helsinki".To remove multi-select group tags for "Campaign:EarlyBird" and "Campaign:Friends", you can use "---Campaign:EarlyBird,---Campaign:Friends". For details, see Removing security values with three minuses (---).

Use the following syntax to import / update profile information: <key>=<value>:<type>#<key>=<value>:<type> etc. Note that importing checkbox fields requires you to use the type "boolean" and importing date fields requires you to use the type "date" in the syntax. Profile import allows you to add or modify profile values with a specific key - existing profile values are not replaced / removed unless you specifically include their key within the import syntax. You can use three minuses (---) syntax to remove an attribute value. For example: ---<key>. For details, see Removing security values with three minuses (---).

Define as a number: 1 = Canada, US, France, Germany, Italy, Denmark, Sweden, UK after July 2005 (2,2,3) 2 = South Africa (2,3,4) 3 = UK prior to July 2005 (1,3,NaN) 4 = Finland (1,8, NaN) 0 = Other If you define a reference index convention between 1 - 4, then calculation mode and lags are automatically set according to the selected contention. If 0, then you can use parameters in columns #65, #66, and #67.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 65 s.referenceIndexCalculationMode No Reference index calculation mode Define as a number: 1 = Direct 2 = Linear Only available if the Reference index convention in column #64 is set to 0.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 66 s.referenceIndexlag1 No Reference index lag 1 Define the lag in months as a number between 1 - 12. Only available if the Reference index convention in column #64 is set to 0.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 67 s.referenceIndexlag2 No Reference index lag 1 Define the lag in months as a number between 1 - 12. Only available if the Reference index convention in column #64 is set to 0.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 68 s.securityExCosts No Ex-ante / Ex-post costs Security-specific Ex-ante / Ex-post costs. Use the syntax <date 1>:<cost category code 1>=<cost percentage as a number>: <cost category code 2>=<cost percentage as a number>:calculationBase=<0 or 1 for the market value to use for the day (optional parameter), where 0 is ingoing market value and 1 is the same day market value>, <date 2>:<cost category code 1>=<cost percentage as a number>:<cost category code 2>=<cost percentage as a number>:calculationBase=<0 or 1 for the market value to use for the day (optional parameter), where 0 is ingoing market value and 1 is the same day market value>. E.g. (without spaces) 01.01.2018: exPostSecCostCat1=0.2: exAnteSecCostCat7=1.3:calculationBase=0, 01.01.2019: exPostSecCostCat3=0.3:calculationBase=0 You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones. For details, see Updating securities. Available cost category codes: Ex-ante costs: exAnteSecCostCat1 = One off charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat2 = On-going charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat3 = Transaction charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat4 = Ancillary service charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat5 = Incidental charges (%) exAnteSecCostCat6 = Other costs 1 (%) exAnteSecCostCat7 = Other costs 2 (%) exAnteSecCostCat8 = Other costs 3 (%) exAnteSecCostCat9 = Other costs 4 (%) exAnteSecCostCat10 = Other costs 5 (%) Ex-post costs: exPostSecCostCat1 = One off charges (%) exPostSecCostCat2 = On-going charges (%) exPostSecCostCat3 = Transaction charges (%) exPostSecCostCat4 = Ancillary service charges (%) exPostSecCostCat5 = Incidental charges (%) exPostSecCostCat6 = Other costs 1 (%) exPostSecCostCat7 = Other costs 2 (%) exPostSecCostCat8 = Other costs 3 (%) exPostSecCostCat9 = Other costs 4 (%) exPostSecCostCat10 = Other costs 5 (%)

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 69 s.baseCurrency (Yes) Base currency Base currency of the currency cross security, define with the currency code. Base currency is only available for securities of the type "Currency cross" - for "Currency cross" type securities, base currency is a mandatory field!

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 70 s.holidayCalendar No Holiday calendar Define with the holiday calendar code. Built-in holiday calendars' codes: NoHolidays = No holidays/weekends (NoHolidays) Sat/Sun = Saturday/Sunday weekends (SatSun) Fri/Sat = Friday/Saturday weekends (FriSat) Thu/Fri = Thursday/Friday weekends (ThuFri) GBLO = London, United Kingdom (GBLO) FRPA = Paris, France (FRPA)DEFR = Frankfurt, Germany (DEFR) CHZU = Zurich, Switzerland (CHZU) EUTA = European Union TARGET system (EUTA) FIHE = Helsinki, Finland (FIHE) USGS = United States Government Securities (USGS) USNY = New York, United States (USNY) NYFD = Federal Reserve Bank of New York (NYFD) NYSE = New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) JPTO = Tokyo, Japan (JPTO) AUSY = Sydney, Australia (AUSY) BRBD = Brazil (BRBD) CAMO = Montreal, Canada (CAMO) CATO = Toronto, Canada (CATO) CZPR = Prague, Czech Republic (CZPR) DKCO = Copenhagen, Denmark (DKCO) HUBU = Budapest, Hungary (HUBU) MXMC = Mexico City, Mexico (MXMC) NOOS = Oslo, Norway (NOOS) NZAU = Auckland, New Zealand (NZAU) NZWE = Wellington, New Zealand (NZWE) PLWA = Warsaw, Poland (PLWA) SEST = Stockholm, Sweden (SEST) ZAJO = Johannesburg, South Africa (ZAJO) Or use the code of your custom holiday calendar defined in preferences.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 71 s.settlementDateOffset No Settlement date offset Define the settlement date offset as a number of days.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 72 s.enableSettlementDateOffset No Enable settlement date offset Define as a number: 1 = Enabled 0 = Not enabled If no value is filled in, the default value 0 "Not enabled" is used.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 73 s.stubConvention No Stub convention Define with a code: None = None ShortInitial = Short initial LongInitial = Long initial SmartInitial = Smart initial ShortFinal = Short final LongFinal = Long final SmartFinal = Smart final Both = Both

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 74 s.businessDayConvention No Business day convention Define with a code: ModifiedFollowing = Modified following (without crossing month end) Nearest = Nearest ModifiedPreceding = Modified preceding (without crossing month start) Following = Following ModifiedFollowingBiMonthly = Modified following (without crossing mid-month or month end) NoAdjust = No adjustment Preceding = Preceding

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 75 s.exCouponPeriod No Ex-coupon period Define the ex-coupon period as a number of days.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 76 s.yieldConvention No Yield convention Define with a code: GB-Bump-DMO = UK BUMP/DMO method US-Street = US street DE-Bonds = German bonds JP-Simple = Japan simple yield

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 77 s.macaulayDuration No Macaulay duration Define as date-value pairs as a comma-separated list with the format <yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,<yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>. E.g. 2019-01-01=7.1,2019-04-01=1.1 You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones. For details, see Updating securities.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 78 s.modifiedDuration No Modified duration Define as date-value pairs as a comma-separated list with the format <yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,<yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>. E.g. 2019-01-01=7.1,2019-04-01=1.1 You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones. For details, see Updating securities.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 79 s.convexity No Convexity Define as date-value pairs as a comma-separated list with the format <yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,<yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>. E.g. 2019-01-01=7.1,2019-04-01=1.1 You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones. For details, see Updating securities.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 80 s.offsetDays No Offset days Define as a number.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 81 s.tenor No Tenor Define the tenor for your security with alternatives: 1D, 2D, 3D 1W, 2W, 3W, 4W, 6W, 13W, 26W, 52W 1M, 2M, 3M, 4M, 5M, 6M, 7M, 8M, 9M, 10M, 11M, 15M, 18M, 21M 1Y, 2Y, 3Y, 4Y, 5Y, 6Y, 7Y, 8Y, 9Y, 10Y, 11Y, 12Y, 13Y, 14Y, 15Y, 20Y, 25Y, 30Y, 35Y, 40Y, 45Y, 50Y

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 82 s.ytm No YTM Define as date-value pairs as a comma-separated list with the format <yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,<yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>. E.g. 2019-01-01=7.1,2019-04-01=1.1 You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones. For details, see Updating securities.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 83 s.keyFigures No Key figures Define the key figure code and individual observations as date-value pairs as a comma-separated list with the format <code>=<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>:<code>=<date:yyyy-MM-dd>=<value>,... E.g. AAA=2009-01-01=1.9,2010-01-01=1.10:TAX=2007-01-01=1,2010-01-01=2 When importing categorized key figures (e.g. 1=Low, 2=Medium, 3=High), prior to 3.7.7 you should use the "number" (e.g. 1, 2 or 3), and after 3.7.7 you should use the "text" (e.g. Low, Medium, High). You can use *** syntax to add new observations to the list and keep the existing ones. For details, see Updating securities.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 84 s.rollConvention No Roll convention Define with a code: DAY_1 = 1st day of the month DAY_2 = 2nd day of the month DAY_3 = 3rd day of the month, and so on. DAY_MON = Monday DAY_TUE = Tuesday DAY_WED = Wednesday DAY_THU = Thursday DAY_FRI = Friday DAY_SAT = Saturday DAY_SUN = Sunday EOM = End of month (EOM) IMMNZD = First Wednesday on or after the ninth day of the month (IMMNZD) TBILL = Next Monday (TBILL) SFE = Second Friday (SFE) IMM = Third Wednesday (IMM) IMMAUD = Thursday before the second Friday (IMMAUD) IMMCAD = Two days before the third Wednesday (IMMCAD) NONE = None

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 85 s.linkedPortfolio No Linked portfolio Define with the portfolio ID of the linked portfolio. The linked portfolio must exist in the system. Linked portfolio is used e.g. to link a fund portfolio to your fund security. (Available from FA 3.9 onward)

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 86 s.votesPerShare No Votes per share The number of votes this security has per share.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 87 s.source No Price source The method to determine the close market price for the security. To use the first available price in the Manual, Close 1, 2, 3, 4 or 5 columns in the Security window, Market data info tab (checking the column values in the order specified above), specify Default. To determine a different priority of price source fields, enter a comma-separated list of columns in the order of priority. The values are: Manual, Close 1, Close 2, Close 3, Close 4, Close 5. You can use *** syntax to add new values in the list of price source fields and keep the existing ones. For details, see Updating securities. You can use three minuses (for example, ---Close 1) to remove a value.

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 88 s.collateralRatio No Collateral ratio Collateral ratio is a percentage of a position's market value that can be used to calculate collateral value for portfolio credit. The field can be empty. Use the following format: YYYY-MM-DD=XX (where XX is the collateral ratio value). For example: 2023-12-10=45, 23-11-09=30

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 89 s.paymentType No Payment type Payment type for bonds. Define as a number: 0 = Payment in cash1 = No payment, accrued coupons2 = Payment in kind, accrued coupons

title: FA Format for importing securities

You can use *** to add new static groups to the security while keeping the existing ones. For example: ***, <group code>. For details, see Updating securities.

title: FA Format for importing securities

title: FA Format for importing securities
body: 92 s.redemptionSchedule
